Blessed is the man whose delight is in the Law of the Lord, and who doth meditate in his Law both day and night. The Iesuite is a Iebusite. Be ashamed ô Iesuite of thy proud blasphemous lying title, and be content hereafter to call thy selfe a Iebusite, for whilst thou banishest men and women from Scripture, thou hearest blessed Iesus, sending men and women to Scripture, yea, commanding them to search Scripture, for be not these his words:Iohn. 5. 35. Search the Scriptures, for in them you thinke to haue eternall life, and they are they which testifie of me. Heare I not Iesus faithfull seruant charging the Colossians thus: Let the word of God dwell in you plentiously. Where the Spirit of God will haue the whole elect of God, men, women, old, and yong, learned, and vnlearned, to be as it were as so many buildings; & this
blessed word of God contained in Scripture to be as a guest not lodging for one night but dwelling alwayes to the end in them. That famous Bishop Chrysostome handling this text at Constantinople, tooke occasion thereupon to deale with his people, to prouide themselues of Bibles, at the least of the new Testament, to the end that the husband with the wife, and the parents with the children might conferre at home vpon the misteries of their saluation, praying them not to lay the whole burthen therof vpon his shoulders. For Chrysostome had not learned to blindfold the babes of God so, that they could thinke themselues sufficient certified of life eternall, if they could beleeue as the Church beleeued, albeit in the meane time they knew not what the Church beleeued.Theod lib. 5. de cor. grec. affec. Theodoretus hath a worthy place to this purpose. Ye may cōmonly see that our doctrine is knowne not onely of them that are doctors of the Church, and ministers of the people, but also euen of the Taylors, and Smithes, and Weauers, and of women, and that not onely of learned, but of vnlearned, and labouring women, and sempsters and
seruants, and hand-maids, neither onely the citizenes, but also the countrie folkes do verie well vnderstand the same. Ye may find euen the verie diggers, and the neat-heards, and the gardeners, disputing of the holy Trinitie, and of the creation of all things. Were these holy Fathers, (who sometimes sed the babes of God with the holy truth of God) liuing now? I thinke they would condemne these hellish foxes, who by their cruell hands slay the bodies of the babes of God, and by their lying lippes murther their soules.Hieron. ad dem. I heare Hierom saying, ô my soule, Ignoratio Scripturarum, ignoratio Christi est; ama Scripturas sanctas, & amabit te sapientra: vt magis est voluntatem Domini facere quam • osse, The hurt cometh by the ignorance of Scripture. ita prius est nosse quam facere. The ignorance of the Scripture, is the ignorance of Christ; loue holy Scriptures, and wisdome shall loue thee: as it is a greater thing to do the will of God, then to know it, so it must be first knowne before it be done. I wonder how the Iesuite taketh that speech of Augustine. Si Scripturas diuinas aut non legimus ipsi, aut legentes alios libenter non audimus, ipsa nobis medicamenta conuertantur in vulnera, & inde habemus iudicium
vnde potuimus habere remedium. If either we our selues reade not holy Scripture, or gladly heare not others reading them vnto vs, our verie medicine shall be turned vnto woundes vnto vs: and of that we shall reape condemnation, of the which we might haue found health and saluation. Obiection. I am not ignorant, ô my soule, that the Popish seminarie keeping vp holy Scripture from the common people,That alledged benefit of ignorance & hurt, of reading Scripture remoued. and thereby detaining them within the darke schoole of ignorance, alledgeth most clearely (euen against his conscience, albeit with a brasen countenance) that he doth this for the singular spirituall benefite of the common people: for is not ignorance (if we may tell the Seminarie) the mother of Deuotion? and doth not the reading of Scripture bring simple people vnder fearefull heresies? Hearken neuer, ô my soule, vnto the deceiuing and male-pert, lying Priest making this allegation. Answer. Iohn 4. Ignorance a fearefull mother of vile superstion & vncouth be resi • . For I assure thee, being clearely taught of God, that howbeit ignorance hath bene the onely mother of abominable idolatrie, and superstitious deuotion, making poore soules with the deceiued Samaritans to worship that which they know not, and
with the superstitious Athenians to set vp an altar vnto an vnknowne God, yet ignorance was neuer, neither euer shall be the mother of that true religious deuotion commanded by God, allowed of God, and comfortable for the soule of man. Ignorance hath bene, and euer shall proue the mother of heresie, drawing men from the true God, yea making men (who professe themselues to know the true God) to worship and to seeke him falsly.Esay 8. 19. 20. O Isaiah was this doctrine vented by thy cleane lips which were touched with that coale which was taken of ye altar of God, which now the vncleane lips of the foule Seminarie toucheth, who hath his conscience feared with a hot iron heat in the fire of the bottomles pit. No, no, for I heare Isaiah speaking thus to me: Should not a people inquire at their God; from the liuing to the dead, to the Law and the testimonie, if they speake not according to this word, it is because there is no light in them. And so Isaiah here, ô my soule, maketh ignorance to be the manifest and direct mother of vile heresie. Doth blessed Iesus that true teacher of the truth of God speake of ignorance as the false Iesuite speaketh of
it? not I thinke: for heare I him not thus speaking to the Saduces: You erre not knowing the Scriptures and the power of God. Teaching them therby that the ignorance of the Scripture made them to denie that rarest article of the beleefe, euen the resurrection of our bodies; and consequently that ignorance is the vile mother of vile heresie. Yea hearest thou not, ô my soule, that holy one thy Sauiour crying thus on the Crosse:Mat. 22. 19. Father forgiue them, for they know not what they are doing: Lact. lib. 5. resoluing vs hereby, that Ignorance is the fierce mother of bloudie persecution. Lactantius was not of the Papists opinion, albeit he writ that with his penne which the Seminaries conscience must subioyne vnto: for giuing his reason wherefore so few of the world did consent vnto the onely true sauing truth of God, he saith; Multi ob • urant se contra manifestam veritatem, non cogitant quare sint nati; haec enim prauitatis est causa, ignoratio sui: Manie do harden their hearts against the manifest truth of God: they consider not wherefore they were borne. For this is the cause and ground of wickednesse, and shreudnesse, when a man knowes not himselfe, and how can
he know himselfe possibly, who out of Scripture hath not learned to know God and himselfe. Bernard w • o liued in a very corrupt time was of another iudgement then the Iesuites now be of: for he could write thus touching ignorance. Pessimae matris ignorantiae pessimae itidem filiae duae sunt; falsitas, & dubitatio, illa miserior, haec miserabilior, perniciosa illa, ista molestior. Cum loquitur Spiritus • adit vtraque, & non est solum veritas, What moued the Pope to be so carefull to haue the holy Scripture kept vp from the babes of God. sed & certa veritas. There be two most mischieuous daughters of that mischieuous mother, Ignorance; Falsitie, and Doubting, that more miserable, this more to be pitied, that pernitious, this troublesome. When the spirit speaketh, they both do fall to the ground, and then not onely is a truth, but a certaine truth. Now in all their respects may it not be asked (euen with admiration) what should moue the Pope with his followers to be so earnestly, & carefully, to haue that sacred volume of holy Scripture kept vp from the babes of God. Hearken, hearken, ô my soule, well know they what holy Scripture is, and what is to be found in it: and therefore therefore they cannot suffer, they will not suffer the babes of God to haue it, lest
they (led by Scripture) should be made to know that which they know, Scripture cannot but leade them vnto. What thefe approaching a house of purpose to breake it, desires to heare the crow of the cocke, or the barke of the dogge, to see any candle, or to be brought before any gallous? for well knowes he that the crow of the cocke, or the barke of the dogge may waken some one within, and so hinder him of his intent: and he cannot be ignorant that the candle will deceiue him, & the gallous destroy him. Now no lesse clearely knowes the Papist, Scripture to be that to him (in case it were knowne by the common people) which the crow of the cocke, the barke of the dogge, the light of the candle, aud sight of the gallous is to these. This moued Chrysostome long ago thus to write touching Heretickes.Chrysost op. imp. Hom. 44. Heretici sacerdotes, claudunt ianuas veritatis. Sciunt enim si manifesta esset veritas quod ipsorum ecclesia esset relinquenda, & ipsi de sacerdotali dignitate ad humilitatem venirent popularem. Hereticall Priests do close vp the gates of the truth of God: for they know that if that truth were made manifest, and cleare to the world; that
their Church would be forsaken, and that they themselues would be cast downe from their priestly dignitie vnto the meanest estate of the basest people. Hireom. in Esa. lib. 9. cap. 30. This moued Hierome also thus to write touching Heretickes. Sagittant in obscuro rectos corde, istitantam sibi assumunt authoritatem, vt siue dextra doceant, siue sinistra, id est siue bona, siue mal • , nolunt discipulos ratione discutere, sed se praeceptores sequi; tunc hi qui prius decipiebant nequaquam vltro ad eos volebant accedere, postquam se senferint intellectos. They shoote their darts in secret at the vpright in heart. These men challenge so great authoritie to themselues, that whither they teach right, or wrong, that is, good or euill; they will no wayes haue their disciples to trie, or examine that they teach but to follow their maisters blindnesse: then these who first deceiued the people, would not afterwards come to them knowing that they were vnderstood and taken vp. I perswade my selfe, ô my soule, were that worthy man Petrus Ferrariensis liuing to day, he would (directing his speech to the Princes of the world and specially of Europe) crie out as he did of old. O miseros imperatores & seculares Principes! qui haec & alia sustinetis, & vos
seruos ecclesiae facitis, & mundum per eos infinit is modis vsurpari videtis, nec de remedio cogitatis, & quia prudētiae & sapientiae non attēditis. O miserable Emperours and Princes of the world! who suffer these & other things, & make your selues seruants of the Church, and see the world innumerable wayes abused by them, and yet do thinke vpon no remedie, because you hearken not vnto prudence and wisedome. For sure it is if the Princes and people (misled this day by the Papists) knew what God offers to them by Scripture, what God craues of them by Scripture, and how their leaders should carrie themselues towards him, they would not be misled any longer by them. No, no, Iehu was neuer more forward in destroying the altars of Baal, 2. King. 10. then they would be readie to pull downe all their idolatrous monuments.Acts 16. Those men of Ephesus were not more willing to burne their costly curious bookes, after they hard and beleeued, then the Kings, the Princes and the men, the women; now blindnesse followes the blind Papists, would be to burne all those pamphlets and monuments of poperie put in their hands by thē. And to conclude this point, sure I am
were Augustine liuing this day,Aug. Epist. 167. he would direct his speech, against the Popish Seminaries as he directed it long ago against the Donatists. Puto quod ipse diabolus, si authoritate Iudicis quem ipse eligeret, toties vinceretur, non esset tam impudens vt in ea causa persisteret. In my iudgement if the diuell himselfe were so often ouercome by the authoritie of the Iudge whom he had chosen to himselfe, he would not be so impudent as to persist in that cause. The Papist is bewitched by foure intising Dalilaes so that he cannot be reclaimed. But alas, but alas, ô my soule, these sonnes of that sonne of perdition, be so bewitched by these foure entycing and perswading Dalilaes to the which by fearefull oathes they haue married themselues the onely builders and vpholders of that their Babel, (Auaritia, Superbia, Ignoratio Scripturae, falsorum Prophetarum admiratio. Couetousnes, Pride, Ignorance of the Scripture, admiration of false teachers) that nothing can reclaime them. For my owne part, I pray God for the sonne of his loues sake,Lact. lib. 4. cap. 30. when it shall please him to enlighten the eyes of the Papist Seminaries to see that, and to open their mouthes to confesse that euen before the simplest of the babes of God which Chrysostome confessed to be most
true touching holy Scripture.Chrysost, hom. 3. de Lazaro. Magna aduersus peccatum munitio est Scripturarum lectio, magnum praecipitium, profundum barathrum scripturarum ignoratio: magna salutis perditio de diuinis legibus nihil sc • re, eares haereses peperit, ea vitam corruptaminuexit, hoc sursum deorsum miscuit omnia. The reading of holy Scripture is a great fortresse against sinne. The ignorance of holy Scripture is a verie fearefull downefall to the deepest and most dangerous dungeon. It is a great losse of saluation to know nothing of the Lawes of God: this hath bred heresie; this hath brought in corrupt life, and vile manners; yea, this hath turned all things vp and downe.

div.head: THE SECOND ROBBER is the Popish Seminarie, without conscience, and with ashameles countenance, blotting cleane, perfect written Scripture; with the foule blot of imperfection and subtiltie, obtruding to the babes of God • ound Traditions.
div.p:
THat euill one Satan,Satan ha
• eth Scripture deadly being neuer able to forget that sensible foyle he receiued
at the hands of yt great Sauiour of the world Iesus (drawing that two edged sword of holy Scripture,Mat. 4. ouer, and ouer, against him, euen while Satan cunningly peruerting Scripture, pressed by bringing of it against him, to abuse it to his ouerthrow) hath alwayes kept in his heart, a deadly vnrecouerable hatred against holy Scripture; and therefore he hath not contented himselfe by the crafty and cruell trauels of the Popish Seminarie onely, to hide vp that cleare light which shineth in holy Scripture, from the eyes of Gods babes. But besides this he hath not bene affraid (so shameles is that great enemie the god of this world, so forward are these his agents first blinded and then sent forth by him) euen to accuse holy Scripture of a most grosse fault, and blast it with a monstrous blemish, holding and affirming, that euen Scripture (the verie inditement of truth) onely louing, onely pitifull, onely towards the babes of God; louing them with a loue vnspeakable and glorious: pitying them with incomparable compassion: and well knowing what they stand in neede of, for keeping of them from
Satan and sinnes snare, and for leading them straightly towards their expected home) is no perfect booke containing in it all things necessarie for mans saluation, but imperfect, which must be supplied (as they alledge) by their traditions and vnwritten verities (as they call them) which they affirme to be worthy of no lesse reuerence, and authoritie then the verie written word of God deliuered by the Prophets of blessed Iesus, and his Apostles: as that shamelesse first decree pronounced from the deceiued and deceiuing hearts, by the foule and defyling lips of those apostat fathers of yt Councell of Trent in that 4. Session plainely speaketh. Now (which thou canst not but iustly admire) ô my soule, the Popish Seminarie hath so farre preuailed in this point also, with the Euahes of this time, with the Sampsons of this time, that as they will not looke, vpon any condition almost, vpon a Bible translated in their mother tongue, so they will euen with greedinesse lend both their eares vnto the found traditions of the Popish Seminaries, albeit they be the corrupt birth of his owne brutish braine. Pitie ô God the Euahes of
this our time, hearkening vnto the Serpent, but not to the Sauiour. Pitie ô God that Sampsons of this time, hearkening vnto the agents of that trecherous great Dalilah, but not vnto that true glorious Messias. Oh, ô my soule, what a world of auditors and followers, found those blind leaders of the blind Scribes and Pharises, while thy Lord and Maister teaching in the world, was forsaken of all? and therefore wonder not while he is not teaching in his owne person, but by his base seruants, lying flatterers be honoured and maintained, and that the onely true fathers of the Church be condemned, and murthered.The Pope and his be possessed by a strange spirit. This must be a strang Spirit, ô my soule, which possesseth the Pope, which possesseth his agents, yea, which possesseth those who do follow him and them, that he with them hath taken vpon them to perfect holy Scripture as if in it selfe it were maimed, and not onely to darken it as if it were not cleare, but besides this that they haue found credit in these points with the Euahes and Sampsons of this world. The written word of God my Father I may not reade, I may not heare in my mother tongue. And yet
the vnwritten inuentions of man I my reade, I must reade in any tongue I can vnderstand. That Scripture which leades men thus, ô my soule, cannot possibly be the spirit of the Father, the spirit of the Sonne who is from aboue, but must be some spirit who is from beneath, drawing men from the true Father and Sauiour of their soules, to some bastard father and Sauiour, who in the end will proue an vnnaturall Saul, seeking the life of his owne Ionathan, and a cruell Herod murthering those infants he should haue maintained. Scripture condemnes, and all ages since that time sensible of God, haue abhorred Ieroboam the sonne of Nebat, for attempting (contrarie to the will of God) to erect an altar at Bethel, and another at Dan, lest the people resorting to Ierusalem (where God had appointed sacrifice onely to be offered) should haue fallen away from him to the house of Dauid: and shall not God condemne, and should not all men sensible of God abhorre these peart Popish Seminaries who haue taken vpon them to set vp in euery corner where they can be heard, the calfes of their owne traditions, drawing away men thereby from
the true oracles of Gods written word, lest that they ceassing to dote after these calfes, and hearkening to Gods oracles, should giue themselues to seeke and serue the liuing God, according to his commandement? Now to the effect that the Seminarie may make the calfes of his traditions to shine the more brightly, and to smile the more sweetly on such towards whom they are drawne, they haue not bene afraid to lay a most fearefull imputation vpon our blessed God, and his sacred truth; most lyingly (and yet most boldly) affirming that all things requisite for mans saluation be not contained in holy Scripture. What, ô my soule, if the eyes of men were enlightened with the eyes of Dauid, to see the wonders of the Law of God, and seeing these wonders to perceiue, not that little drop, but that huge quantitie of sweetest honie, the hungrie child of God hath presented to his soule by the Spirit, speaking vnto him by that 4. verse of the 15. Chapter of that Epistle written to the Romans, and by the 15. and 16. verses of the 3. Chapter of that second Epistle written to Timothie? Beleeue me, ô my soule, couldst thou weigh and consider
those two Scriptures aright, thou shouldest find thy selfe euen by fiue words (which I may iustly stile fiue bright diamonds Almightie God will haue alwayes to shine vpon the fiue fingers of his owne, to direct their way wheresoeuer they walke) shortly (yet most substantially) acquainting thee so with the whole vses of that blessed written word of God, that thou shouldst be able to find that nothing requisite to mans saluation is deficient in it,Scripture containes all things requisite for mans saluation. that all things needfull to mans saluation be fully & clearly contained in it. Wilt thou not confesse, ô my soule, that whatsomeeuer can concerne mans saluation possibly, must either looke to doctrine or to manners, or to comfort. If it looke to doctrine, that doctrine is either true which the child of God must seeke after, and embrace, as he would seeke after that meate which is onely able to feede him, and after that medicine which is only able to cure him; or false, which the child of God must flie from, as he would flie from poyson, slaying not his bodie onely, but his soule also. If the doctrine be true, that is abundantly and clearly taught by holy Scripture, and therefore it is said
to be profitable to Teach. If the doctrine be false, that holy Scripture discouers clearly and ouerthrowes fully, and therefore it is said to be profitable to Improue. If it looke to manners, these manners be either good, commanded and commended of God: or euill, forbidden and condemned by him. If they be good manners, Scripture instructs them abundantly concerning them: and therefore it is said to be profitable to Instruct in righteousnesse. If the manners be euill, this Scripture reproues and condemnes, and therefore it is said to be profitable to Correct. And lastly, if thou, ô my soule, shalt finde thy selfe cast downe at any time, or weakened by the force of any tentation or crosse lying on thee, or approaching neare thee, shalt thou not find holy Scripture sufficiently able to furnish thee with Patience,Rom. 25. 4. with Comfort, and with Hope, as Paul tels thee? ô my soule, when shall the blind Papist begin to lend his eare vnto holy Scripture, which is that onely old and true antiquitie, which hath God that glorious Ancient of dayes for the author of it, to the end that he may first see that there is no suspition of imperfection of
insufficiencie in holy Scripture, and therefore be moued to confesse, that all things, and euerie thing requisite for mans saluation is onely to be sought out of it, is onely to be found in it. Shall thy God, ô my soule, be so carefull about the building of that outward tabernacle, which he appointed onely to stand for a while, that euen after he had called and fitted Bezaliel & Aholiah for the building of it, he will haue it, and euerie thing belonging to it, to be made after that fashion which was shewed by his Maiestie vnto Moses in the mount? And canst thou, ô my soule, or any other soule with thee, be possibly built (by these men called of God for the worke of the Ministerie) vpon that onely true foundation, and pretious corner stone Iesus, otherwayes then Almightie God hath taught these men to build them vppon him, in and by that his mountaine of holy Scripture? Are we not thus resolued by that disciple whom Iesus loued, ô my soule:Ioh. 20. 29. 30. Many other things also did Iesus in the presence of his disciples, which are not written in this Booke; but these things are written that we might beleeue that Iesus is that Christ the Sonne of God, and that in beleeuing
ye might haue life through his name. Heare I not Paul crying with a loude voice to the hearing of Angels and men? Though that we or an Angell from heauen preach vnto you otherwise then that which we haue preached vnto you, Gal. 1. 8. let him be accursed. If any man teach otherwayes, and consenteth not vnto the wholsome words of the Lord Iesus Christ, and to the doctrine which is according to godlinesse, he is puft vp and knoweth nothing, 1. Tim. 6. 3. 4. 5. but doteth about questions, and strife of words, whereof cometh enuie, strife, raylings, euill surmisings, vaine disputations of men of corrupt minds, and destitute of the truth, which thinke that gaine is godlinesse, from such separate thy selfe. Thinkest thou that it was without cause, ô my soule, that our God directed the Iewes thus by the mouth of Moses, to whom the Law was giuen?Deut. 4. • . & 12. 32. Ye shall put nothing to the word which I command you, neither shall ye take ought therefrom that ye may keepe the commandements of the Lord your God which I command you. Was it without cause that blessed Iesus by whom grace came to vs, would speake thus to vs by the mouth of his dearest seruant Iohn? For I protest vnto euery man that heareth the words of the prophecie
of this booke: If any man shall adde vnto these things, God shall adde vnto him the plagues that are written in the booke. Reuel. 22. 18. 19. And if any man shall diminish of the words of this prophecie, God shall take away his part out of the booke of life, and out of the holy Citie, and from these things written in this Booke. Oh, ô my soule, when shall the blind Papist proudly (albeit not onely vainely but falsly) bragging of Antiquitie, countenance that Antiquitie penned by men, led of God by Scripture, and in Gods name leading men to Scripture, to the end that they with these men may see the sufficiencie and perfection of Scripture, and with this, the vanitie, the weaknesse, the vilenesse of humane traditions. Origen who was no Papist, albeit he wrote long ago, wrote thus:Origen in Ierem. Nobis necesse est Scripturas sanctas in testimonium vocare; sensus quippe nostri, & enarrationes sine his testibus non habent fidem. We must necessarily call holy Scripture to beare witnesse to vs, for without them neither can our conceptions nor expositions haue any faith. Chrysostome seeing no imperfection in Scripture could say: Si quid dicitur absque Scriptura, Chrysost. auditorum cogitatio claudicat. Whatsoeuer is deliuered or
spoken without the warrant of Scripture maketh the mindes of the herers to halt. Damascene agreeing herewith, can say: Cuncta quae tradita sunt per legem, Damas. per Prophetas, per Apostolos, & Euangelistas suscipimus, cognoscimus, veneramur, nihil vltro perquirentes. We receiue and admit, we acknowledge and reuerence whatsoeuer is deliuered to vs by the Law, by the Prophets, and by the Euangelists, searching out nothing beside. Augustine subscribing hereto could say: Quod è Scriptura authoritatem non habet, August. eadem facilitate contemnitur quae probatur. Whatsoeuer hath not authoritie from Scripture, is as easily contemned as it is allowed. O would to God that those kings and subiects, parents and children, husbands and wiues, maisters and seruants, who superstitiously dote after the Pope and his traditions, could hearken to that of Cyprian, deliuered to the inhabitants of Carthage his auditors: Adulterum est, Cypr. ep. 4. ad pleb. Carth. impium est, sacrilegum est, quodcunque humano furore instituitur, vt dispositio diuina violetur: procul ab huiusmodi hominum contagione discedite, & sermones eorum velut cancer & pestem fugiendo vitate, praemonente Domino & docente, coeci sunt & coecorum duces. Nemo
vos fratres à Domini vijs errare faciat; nemo vos Christianes à Christi Euangelio rapiat; nemo filios Ecclesiae de Ecclesia tollat; pereant sibi qui perire voluerunt, qui mandatum Dei reij • iunt, & traditionem suam statuere conantur; fortiter à vobis & firmiter respuantur; vitate linguam diaboli venenatam, qui ab initio mundi fallax semper, & mendax erat; mentitur vt fallat, blanditur vt noceat, bona promittit vt malum tribuat, vitam pollicetur vt perimat. Whatsoeuer is ordained of the furie of man, to the end that the ordinance of God may be ouerthrowne, that is adulterous, impious, sacrilegious; take your selues farre from the infection of such men, by flying, eschewing their speeches as ye would eschue the canker, and the pest; being forewarned and taught by our Lord and Maister saying vnto you, they be blind leaders of the blind. O my brethren, suffer no man to make you erre from the wayes of the Lord. Let no man pull you Christians from the Gospell of Christ? Let no man take the sonnes of the Church out of the Church; let them perish to themselues who will perish; let those be strongly and constantly reiected and cast off by you, who do cast off the commandements of God, to establish their owne traditions; flie farre
from the diuell his poysoned tongue, who from the beginning of the world hath euer bene a deceiuer, and a lyer; he lies, to the end he may deceiue; he flatters, to the end he may hurt; he promises good things, to the end he may giue thee euill things: yea, he binds himselfe to giue life, to the end he may slay. O when shall the blind Papist hearken to that of Clemens Alexandrinus. In or. ad gent. Quoniam ipsum verbum ad nos venit de coelo, non est amplius eundum, ad hominum doctrinam. Because the very word of God is now come to vs from the heauens, we must not hereafter take our selues to the doctrine of men. This is that the Spirit would cleare vnto vs, when he saith: At sundrie times, Heb. 1. 2. and in diuerse manners, God spake in the old time to our fathers by the Prophets, in the last dayes he hath spoken to vs by his Sonne, by whom also he made the world. O when shall that be heard and beleeued by the Papist.Iustin. in tryph. Sola Christiana Philosophia eiusmodi est, ex qua rerum diuinarum haurienda est cognitio, cuius authores fuerunt homines iusti, Dei amantes, Deo chari, neminem metuentes, gloriae non cupidi, tantum Spiritus Dei afflatu loquuti. Christian wisedome contained in holy Scripture is onely such, out of the which knowledge of heauenly
things is onely to be drawne, the authors whereof were men iust, louing God, dearely beloued of God, fearing no man, no waies desirous of glorie and honour, aud who did speake by the inspiration of the holy Ghost onely.

div.head: THE THIRD ROBBER IS the Popish Seminarie, malitiously stealing from the child of God that perfect satisfaction made by blessed Iesus, his sole and full Sauiour, vnto God his Father for all his sinnes, and for all punishment due to him for his sinnes; and cunningly obtruding vnto him his owne satisfaction for the temporarie punishment of his sinnes, either here before death, or after death in Purgatorie.
div.p:
O What a terrifying monster hath that cunning foxe the Pope made of his more then subtilly inuented,The Papist hath made a fearefull monster of his effectlesse fire of Purgatorie. and yet more thē shamefully vented, of the effectlesse fire of Purgatorie? Beleeue me, ô my foule, those huge giants the sons of Anak, bred neuer such dashing astonishment vnto the faithlesse and murmuring spies, and
people of Israel, as these flames of the fire of Purgatorie (kindled by the Pope in the cold chimney of his fond imagination, and without it to this day neuer seene, neuer felt burning by any liuing, by any dead) hath and doth procure to those blind people, who turning their backes vpon the word of God, (carried by Moses and Aaron) haue lent their eares to his inuentions. And yet the subtile Pope, to make this his conceit the more plausible, to that blind people led by him their blind guide, can hold & maintaine most peartly, (albeit more then lyingly) that howbeit blessed Iesus hath by his death satisfied God his Fathers wrath,The Popish forged ground of his forged Purgatory. for the guilt of the sinnes of his chosen, and for the eternall punishment due to them for those their sinnes; yet he hath no wayes satisfied for that temporarie punishment their sins drawes after them, and so opening without shame his shamelesse mouth, he dare auow that all these who here do not sufficiently satisfie by Penance (as he speaketh) for their veniall and daily sinnes, must remaine after death in Purgatorie, and be there broyled, and sodden in the flames thereof till they be haled out againe.
This fire the Pope hath taken vpon him to make vp of coales and other matter, neuer created by that great Creator who made all things, but of a matter knowne (I should haue said vnknowne to himselfe.) And this strong fire he hath kindled neither in the heauens, nor in the aire, nor in the seas, nor in the earth, nor in the hells; so that I must thinke, as the Pope doth not know of what matter he hath made vp that his fire of Purgatorie,The alledged extrem paines indured in the forged fire. so he cannot know in what place it burneth. And yet (if the Papist may be beleeued) ô what extreame intollerable paines do poore soules sustaine there? Is not this written by their Doctors for a truth, ô my soule! There was a soule which had bene thirtie yeares in Purgatorie, at length there came an Angell asking his soule whether it would tarrie yet one short Winter day in Purgatorie,In the 160. sermon of the soules of the booke c • lled sermone • discipuli de tempore & sanctis. or if it would returne to the world againe, and do there a maruellous hard Penance; to wit, for a long hundred yeares space go barefooted, still treading vpon sharpe iron nailes, eating nothing but browne bread, drinking bitter gall mingled with vineger, wearing a cloath made of camels
haire nearest his skin, and hauing a stone vnder his head in place of a pillow. This soule hearing this, chused rather to returne to the earth to indure all this, then to stay so much as one short Winter day long in Purgatorie. But no wonder can it be that the soule made her choyse thus, if that fire be such a fire as the Papists make it to be: for is it not written in their decrees, that there is no earthly paine or martyrdome to be compared to the paines of Purgatorie? yea, is that great schooleman Thomas ashamed to affirme?Cap. qui in aliud dist. 25. that the fire of hell and the fire of Purgatorie is all one, and that they differ nothing at all, but that the one is temporall, and the other is eternall. And yet is it not a wonder, ô my soule, that the Papists can write so resolutely touching this their forged fire, and the extremitie of the paines sustained in it, considering that our blessed God (to whom all things are knowne) to this day told vs neuer by Scripture that there was such a fire, or such paines sustained in it; yea, considering that these very Papists by whom these things be written, (as I thinke) will confesse were neuer at Purgatorie, either to
see the flames of fire burning,What moued the Papists to write so freely about their forged fire of Purgatorie. or to heare the cries of the soules tormented there, or to be pained themselues therewith. But ô my soule, it may be that I smell a farre off (if I be not farre deceiued) that which hath moued the Papists so freely thus to speake, and to write about their Purgatorie. The fire of Purgatorie they neuer saw, the ho • e paining flames thereof they neuer felt in their owne persons. But yet they do daily see their owne outward and naturall fire, and feele the heate of it, to their great profit and pleasure: And they know that this their alledged forged fire of Purgatorie, with the alledged fearefull, and forged burning flames thereof, hath onely set vp this their fire, and kept in this their fire; that kings are onely in their hands who are onely able to pull poore soules out of these flames; yea that strongest fleshcrooke is onely in their custodie, which is able to hale them out of this boyling caldron (for be they not the maisters of all Masses, Pardons, and Indulgences, by the which alone these poore soules (if the Papists may be beleeued) are deliuered from these flames? haue they not, non
sine commodo curiae, albeit cum damno conscientiae: first forged that fire cunningly, and to this day fostered it carefully, drawing sharpe slaying swords, and kindling seene deuouring flames of seene, felt fire, against all such who hearing do not beleeue and follow them. And, ô my soule, will Scripture subscribe with the Papist? will true Antiquitie founded on Scripture, and not blinded by that filthie idoll Couetousnesse foster him in this point?Scripture ouerthroweth Purgatorie & her pretended ground. No, no, ô my soule, I assure thee; for if that blessed Spirit of truth speaking by Scripture cleare any point of sauing doctrine sensibly, for the resolution and consolation of poore sinners, against those euils which sinne draweth vpon man, he cleares most sensibly that which that cursed spirit of lyes speaking by the Pope, and his suffraganes obscures most grosly, yea controles and denies most impudently: and yet most heartily vnto the confusion and condemnation of poore sinners. What hath the Spirit of God cleared, ô my soule, if this be not cleared by him? Blessed Iesus, that Sonne of God and Sonne of man, is that sole and onely Sauiour of man, is the full and perfect Sauiour of man; who alone in his owne
person once hath satisfiedfully, and perfited his fathers iustice, for all the sinnes of his elect freeing them from all the guilt of their sinnes, and from all their punishment due to them. Cannot sweet Iesus (who neuer made any foolish bragge, or vttered any apparent vntruth, fastened to the Crosse, and there suffering for thee,Christ alone in his owne person hath satisfied his Father for vs fully. ô my soule) crie out with a loud voice. It is finished, it is finished? by this one word, directing his speech to God his Father who sent him to saue lost men, and telling his Maiestie that he by his death had payed the least farthing of mans debt of sinne, and so satisfie his iustice fully; directing his speech to man, for whose sake he was sent, and telling him that he was loosed from that band, and hand writing, God the Father had ouer his head because of sinne, he hauing cancelled it, and rent it in peeces vpon the tree, and so that he was freed from that prison within the which he lay bound before and set at libertie, henceforth to serue God on earth, and to reigne with him in heauen: & yet the couetous papists alwayes crying (with Iudas) What will you giue me and I will betray him to you? can giue Christ the lie in his face, saying in
the hearing of his father to men, It is not finished. That is, Christ hath not ransomed man fully, and freed him from prison wholely in respect he must go yet to that prison of Purgatorie and by another ransome (most vile indeed, yet not so vile as the vile receiuer of it is) be deliuered therefrom. Cannot Paul (subscribing to the sweetest and most comfortable words of his Maister) tell me that Iefus is giuen me of my God to be my Redeemer,1. Cor. 1. 30. albeit the Pope would send me to Purgatorie, to the end he may be my redeemer? Yea, that he gaue himselfe a ransome for all men, albeit the Pope would send me to Purgatorie,1. Tim. 2. 6. there to be tormented by my selfe, by suffering of torments, and by the liuing belonging to me, by laying downe a ransome of gold, for some masses to be sung for me. Isaiah would make me beleeue (and I dare not but beleeue him better then all the Popes of the world) that I am healed by Christs stripes,Esay 5. • . and yet the Papist will haue me yet to be whipped, for the healing of me, with the burning scourges of the flames of this Purgatorie. Yea, Isaiah in that same place tels me that the chastisement
of my peace was vpon Christ alone, and Paul would assure me that I being iustified by faith haue peace with God through Iesus Christ our Lord, albeit the fierce Papist would send me backe to that bloudie barres of his cruell Purgatorie, there to vndergo a fearefull battell and vndergo a bloudy warrefare: draw neare me,A direct opposition betwixt that spirit which speaketh by Scripture and that spirit speaketh by the Pope. here, ô my soule, and consider I pray thee, but that contradiction which is to be found to be betwixt that spirit of truth speaking to thee by Scripture about this point, and that spirit of lies speaking to thee by the Pope: Scripture tels me that Christ hath fully satisfied his Father for me: The Pope tels me that he hath satisfied him onely in a part. Scripture tels me that Christ satisfied once for me. The Pope tels me that he must be satisfied daily for me; Scripture tels me that he satisfied his Father for me by himselfe in his owne person, bearing our sinnes in his flesh vpon the Crosse: the Pope tels me that I must satisfie my God by suffering in my owne person. Scripture tels me, that he hath satisfied and doth satisfie his Father in vs. No wonder that the Pope doth this, for by this craft he liueth, and therefore
I must giue him leaue, ô my soule, till God (being mercifull vnto him) open his eyes to see that truth which shineth in holy Scripture, to lie about this his forged Purgatorie;Act. 20. as Demetrius the siluer Smith at Ephesus lied about his dead goddesse Diana. True Antiquitie condemneth Purgatorie. But will true Antiquitie, ô my soule, subscribe with the Papist about this his Purgatorie? No, no, if it could be hearkned vnto: for cannot old Cyprian say.Cyprian. con. Deme. Quando istinc excessum fuerit, nullus iam locus poenitentiae, nullus satisfactionis effectus; hic vita, aut tenetur, aut amittitur. So soone as we go hence there remaineth no place of repentance any more, no effect of satisfaction; life is either lost or found here. Bernard could say, Tria sunt loca: Coelum, Terra, Infernus; & habent singula habitatores suos; coelum solos bonos, terra mixtos, Infernus solos malos. There be three places, the Heauens, the Earth, and the Hels; and euerie one of them hath their owne indwellers. The heauens keeping these who be good onely: the earth possessing both good and bad: Bern. in sentent. fol. 117. the hels hauing the wicked onely inclosed within them. And againe, Tres sunt animae status, in corpore, posito corpore, & recepto corpore; primus datus est ei
ad agendam poenitentiam, reliqui duo ad habendam requiem vel poenam scilicet, prout gessit in corpore, siue bonum, siue malum. There be three conditions of the soule, one while it is in the bodie; another when it layes aside the bodie; the third when it takes vp the bodie againe. The first estate is granted to her, to the end she may repent, the other two, to the end she may receiue rest or punishment, as she hath behaued her selfe in her bodie, by doing good or euill. Aug. lib. 5. hypogr. Augustine long before Bernard could write thus. Primum locum fides catholica diuina authoritate regnum credit esse coelorum, secundum gehennam, tertiam ignoramus penitus, imo nec in scripturis sanctis inueniemus: the faith of true Catholike Christians leaning to the authoritie of God, beleeues the first place after this life to be the kingdome of heauen, the second to be the hels, but the third we no wayes know, neither shall find to be in holy Scripture. And no wonder that Augustine writ so, for he could not find that Purgatorie hath that vse which the subtile greedie Papist since his dayes hath fained it to haue; for writes not Augustine thus againe:Aug de ver. Ser. 37. Christus suscipiendo paenam, & non suscipiendo culpam, & culpam & paenam deleuit. Christ by taking
on him the punishment due to vs for sinne, and not the guilt of sinne, hath done away both the guilt and the punishment. Yea, this moued Bernard to bring in that saying, Oportuit liberari in hoc saeculo vt liberos haberet in futuro. It behoued the children of our God to be freed and deliuered from all euill in this life, to the end that God their Father might haue free sonnes and daughters to raigne with him in the world to come. Were that ancient Doctor at Paris liuing now,Frater Michael. Menoti. he would ioyne hands with vs against the Papist in this point, for could he not write thus: Peccator est mercator positus in hoc mundo pro emendo regnum Paradisi, & tantum durant nundinae quantum vita praesens. A sinner is a merchant placed in this world to buy the kingdome of Paradise, and the market or faire in the which he must buy it, indures & lasts as long as this present life shall indure.

div.head:
THE FOVRTH ROBBER is the Popish Seminarie, malciously stealing from the babes of God that cleane bloudie and onely propitiatorie sacrifice offered vnto God the Father by that blessed hie Priest of our soules
Iesus; and subtiltie obtruding to them that vncleane bloudie, and no wayes purging, but alwayes defiling sacrifice of the Masse, offered vp (alas) not vnto God (as the Papist alledgeth) but to the diuell (as he should confesse) by his Masse-Priest.
div.p:
SEing,Wherfore was this vile Masse forged by the Papist. ô my soule, that vile sacrifice of the Masse was first inuented without confidence, & then vented with a shamelesse countenance, specially because of this forged and fained fire of Purgatorie to be a tongs or flesh-hooke, or rather a theeuish Egyptian hand, to pull out money of poore mens purses. Let vs trie if Scripture will fauor the tonges, and flesh-hookes of the Masse, more then it fauors the fire of Purgatory. Sure I am, ô my soule that the first inuenters of this vnbloudie (albeit not vngreedie) sacrifice of that mischeuous monstrous Masse, neuer dreamed that holy Scripture should haue fauored it, or furthered them in maintaining of it, albeit the other venters of it, (non efferentes verum sensum ex Scripturis sed inferentes falsum sensum in Scriptur as: not
bringing forth a true interpretation and meaning out of Scripture, but throwing forcible a false interpretation, and meaning vpon Scripture) haue (peruerting Scripture to their owne condemnation,2. Epist. 3. cap. as Peter speaketh) pressed to make Scripture sound their, way. The name of the Masse the Papist shall not find iu Scripture, and this the most learned among them will not deny, for I perswade my selfe that they are long ago ashamed of that brutish conclusion, gathered by the Doctros of Sarbon at Paris, vpon the end of Pauls Epistles, shewing whence they were written, and sounding in the Latine tongue thus. Missa est, and so forth; affirming that Paul did thereby giue men to vnderstand that they should go to heare Masse on Sunday. And therefore I must pray thee, ô my soule, let me here enquire of the Papist first, what sacrifice this his sacrifice of the Masse is? Secondly, what is that which he sacrificeth when he offereth it vp? and these two questions being answered by him, I shall shew thee (God-willing) what thy God speaketh to thee by his owne mouth out of Scripture, and hath deliuered for thy resolution and establishment
about this point. The Papist will answer thee, ô my soule, that his sacrifice of the Masse is an externall, reall, vnbloudie, propitiatorie sacrifice, in the which the true bodie and bloud of Iesus Christ be offered vp to God his Father, by the Masse priest, vnder the shape, forme, and fashion of bread and wine, and that for the sinnes of the liuing on earth here, and for the dead in Purgatorie. I know, ô my soule, that the Masse priest knowes that he hath no conscience in extolling and defending of this his sacrifice, and yet I cannot but wonder how he hath the face to offer it vp, and to eate it when he hath done with it. Grants he not, ô my soule, that it is an outward sacrifice? now if it be an outward sacrifice, it must necessarily be a visible sacrifice, all outward things being visible? If it be a visible sacrifice, then necessarily that which is offered vp into it must be seene, for how can an outward sacrifice be vnderstood, vnlesse the sacrifice offered vp into it be perceiued? Stoope forwards here, ô my soule, and with courage demand the Masse priest, what he offers vp to God, and so what he vnderstands by
the sacrifice whilst he cals his Masse an outward, reall sacrifice? Himselfe I thinke he offers not vp, himselfe I thinke he vnderstands not by that sacrifice which he offers vp, nor his altar, nor the many ceremonies vsed by him, nor those hundred crosses ouer and ouer made by him. The bodie of Christ, saith the priest, stands by his sacrifice: that I heare, but is Christs bodie in that sacrifice of the Masse outward and visible? aduise with thy senses, by the which outward things are perceiued, ô Masse priest, most sensible of siluer, but altogether senslesse of thy Sauiour, and then if thou hast any conscience, answer me as thou wilt be answerable to God: seest thou the bodie of Christ in this thy sacrifice of the Masse? smellest thou it? tastest thou it? touchest thou it? But the accidents of the bread are seene (alledgeth the Masse priest) as the roundnesse of it, the colour of it, yea the taste and smell of it are also perceiued, and these be outward and externall. That I grant to be true. But alwayes, ô Masse priest, when all this is done, either thou must offer these accidents to God, and these must be thy sacrifice, which thou deniest, or else thou
must offer vp to God an outward visible sacrifice without an outward visible offering, which cannot possibly be: or lastly, that one and the same sacrifice must be outward and inward, visible and inuisible. But it may be, ô my soule, that the Masse priest who hath learned his tongue so grosly to contrarie God, can easily digest these contrarieties. Forget not then, ô my soule, that the Papist doth confesse that Christs bodie is offered vp in the Masse, and yet that it is inuisible in the Masse, and therefore see that thou, throwing his owne false doctrine in his owne soules face, say to him, vpon his owne grounds, that his Masse can be no visible sacrifice, and if it be no visible, that it cannot be outward as he affirmeth.No remission of sins without bloud. But will Scripture agree with an vnbloudie sacrifice promising remission of sinnes? I trow not, ô my soule, for speakes not Scripture thus:Heb. 9. 22. Without shedding of bloud there is no remission. Will Scripture allow the offering vp of Christ by a priest for the sinnes of any? I trow not, ô my soule, • or be not these the speeches of the Spirit:Heb. 10. 10. 11. 12. 13. We are sanctified by the offering vp of the bodie of Iesus Christ once made. Euery Priest appeareth daily ministring,
and ofttimes offereth any manner of offering, which can neuer take away sinnes. But this man after he had offered one sacrifice for sinnes, sitteth for euer at the right hand of God, and from hence forth tarrieth till his enemies be made his footstoole. Heb. 9. 24, 25. 26. 27. 28. For with one offering hath he consecrated for euer them that are sanctified. Christ hath entered into the verie heauen to appeare now in the sight of God for vs, not that he should offer himselfe often, as the high Priests entred into the holy place euery yeare with other bloud, (for then must he haue often suffered since the foundation of the world) but now in the end of the world, hath he appeared once to put away sinne by the sacrificing of himselfe, and as it is appointed to men that they shall once dye, and after that commeth iudgement, so Christ was once offered to take away the sinnes of many, and vnto them that looke for him shall he appeare the second time without sinne vnto saluation. And in that fame place: Christ being an hie Priest of good things to come, Heb. 9. 11. 12. by a greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made with hands, that is not of this building, neither by the bloud of goates, and calues, but by his owne bloud, entred he in once into the holy place, and obtained eternall redemption
for vs. And againe: For such an high Priest it became vs to haue which is holy, Heb. 7. 26. 27. 28. harmelesse, and vndefiled, separate from sinners, and made higher then the heauens, which needeth not daily as these high Priests to offer vp sacrifice, first for his owne sinnes, and then for the peoples; for that did he once when he offered vp himself, for the Law maketh men high priests which haue infirmitie, but the word of the oath which was since the Law maketh the Sonne who is consecrate for euermore. Consider these Scriptures, ô my soule, and then calling to minde the fond conceites of the false greedie priest about his Masse, iudge, I pray thee, how these grounds can possibly stand together: Christs offering once made, and Christs offering not once made; Christs offering once offered, and Christs offering daily offered, yea daily to be offered while the world lasts; Christ once offered, and Christ not once offered, but often to be offered; Christ offered once by himselfe, and to be offered often by the priest. But all these contrarieties be easily digested by that man, ô my soule, who can treade the pathes of the old Scribes and Pharises: for ô how iustly may that be spoken of the Masse priest
this day sacrificing his vnbloudie sacrifice of the Masse, that holding in his forged fire of Purgatorie, he may thereby kindle vp to himselfe, and alwayes keepe in his closet, an hote fire to warme himselfe) which was spoken long ago of the Pharises, of whom Chrysostome writeth thus: Magis cupiebant vt lege manente in vsu essent sacrificia quibus ipsi ditabantur, Chrys. on Mat. 23. hom. 44. non Deus; quam lege cessante, sacrificium iustitiae veniret in vsum, quo Deus delectatur & homines iustificantur. They desired rather, that the Law, these sacrifices standing, might remaine in vse, by the which they were inriched, and not God; then that the Law ceassing that sacrifice of righteousnesse should haue place, with the which alone God is well pleased, and by the which sinfull man is made righteous. Now I appeale to thy conscience, ô Masse priest, whither thou wishest that thy vnbloudie sacrifice of the Masse, whereby thou art inriched, and God is grieued, should stand in constant vigor, as it hath done with thee, or that it should ceasse and be reiected of all men, as it was neuer ordained of God, to the end that all men euerie where might haue recourse onely to that onely bloudie propitiatorie sacrifice
once offered vp by Christ, and neuer to be offered vp againe, albeit it be that onely sacrifice wherein God delighteth, and whereby euerlasting righteousnesse is attained by man. But while the Masse priest finds himselfe thus by Scripture to be straited, with Satan his maister tempting my Sauiour, he dare flie to Scripture, and presse euen by it to make all he hath alledged good (about the retention of the temporarie punishment due to sin) after the guilt thereof and eternall punishment belonging to man,The Popish alledgances for the retention of the temporarie punishmēt after that remission of the guilt and eternal punishmēt. for it is remitted. Reade we not (will the Masse priest say) by Moses, in the 3. of Genesis, that howbeit Adam after his fall was certified by that sweet Euangelicke Sermon sounded i • his eares, that by faith in the seed of the woman promised, he should be freed from the guilt of his sin, and eternall death due thereunto: yet we find that Adam beside this must endure the first death, be cast out of the earthly paradise, and haue his bodie afflicted with many troubles and miseries. Surely reade we not that notwithstanding Dauid had his adulterie and murther remitted, yet he was sharpely punished with temporarie
scourges, for as Scripture tels vs the child which was borne dyed according to Gods threatning: Ammon his sonne defiled Tamar his daughter, Absolon his sonne slue Ammon his brother, yea Absolon his sonne put first his old father out of the doores, & after defiled his concubines before the Sun, whereof it is manifest (saith the Masse priest) that after God hath remitted the great and eternall punishment of sinne to his owne, that they themselues must suffer for the temporarie, either here before death, or after death in Purgatory. Lift vp thine eares, ô my soule, and heare I pray thee, he whom heresie hath once blinded, can very hardly be enlightened by veritie: yea, he who with Iudas seekes the bagge, cannot be kept backe from betraying Iesus, for any thing Iesus can speake to him, Iesus can do to him. If thou hast any conscience, ô Masse priest, tell me as thou wilt answer to God, if no other thing moues our wise God, after he hath freely and fully forgiuen his children for the merits of his dearest child Iesus, to correct and afflict them, but that thereby they may satisfie his iustice for the temporarie punishment due to them
for sinne? If thou shalt suffer Scripture to leade thee, and not thy owne greedie heart to miscarrie thee, thou shalt find that no wayes, for that cause, but for maine other good deeds doth our God so behaue himselfe towards his owne. First, that the bodie of sinne in them may by peece and peece be crucified,Wherfore corrects our God those whō he remitteth. and mortified, least otherwayes they falling forth in new sins should proue dogges returning to their vomite, & swine to their puddle. The sense hereof moued, Dauid to say: It is good for me that I haue bene afflicted, Psal. 119. 71. that I may learne thy statutes. Secondly, this is done by our wise God, to the end that these his corrections may supply ye roome of as many speaking, wise Maisters, alwayes sounding in the eares of Gods children that notable iewell receiued by them, euen the remission of their sinnes, together with the dutie they should discharge vnto God for the same. This moued Dauid in the place alledged to say: Before I was afflicted I went astray, Psal. 119. 67. but now I keepe thy word. Chrysostome Chrysost. seeing this which the Papist cannot see, could say. Deus imponit paenam non exigens supplicia pro peccatis, sed ad futura nos corrigens. God
layes correction vpon his owne, not exacting any punishment for sinnes, but correcting vs for the time to come. Yea, this moued Augustine to say. Res prosphera donum est Dei consolantis, res aduersa donum Dei admonentis. Prosperitie is the gift of God comforting men; aduersitie is the gift of God admonishing men. Thirdly, this is done least sinne (which is both freely and fully remitted of God with all punishment due thereto) should be extenuate and accounted light, either by the committers, or by others looking on them, and in the end not onely excused, but defended by them to their condemnation. This moued the Apostle to say,1. Cor. 11. 32. When we are iudged we are chastened of the Lord, because we should not be condemned with the world. Fourthly, that sinners being thus recōciled to God through the remission of their sinnes, and yet out of his wonderfull, wise loue corrected by him, might alwayes carrie about with them some tokens of that sinne which lodgeth within them, and doth sometime fully burst out of them, leading them alwayes with the sound, to the sight of their blacke feete, and making them to walke more holily, and humbly before
God, crying alwayes with that great Apostle,Rom. 7. 24. O wretched man that I am who shall deliuer me from this bodie of death. Fiftly, to the end that th • se corrections wisely layed vpon them by their God, might haue a solid matter of spirituall exercise to them, not onely acquainting them with the great weaknesse and imperfection of their faith and repentance, but stirring them vp to haue them from day to day, more and more increased and strengthened.August. Augustine seeing this, could write most prudently about this point thus: Posset aliquis dicere, si propter peccatum dixit Deus homini, in sudore vultus tui edes panem tuum & spinas, & tribulos proferit tibi terra; cur fideles post remissionem peccatorum, eosdem dolores patiuntur? Respondet, ante remissionem esse supplicia peccatorum, post remissionem, esse certamina exercitationesque iustorum, Some man might say, if God said vnto man for his sinne, in the sweat of thy face shalt thou eate thy bread, and the earth shall bring forth thrones and thistles to thee: wherefore doth the faithfull after the remission of their sins suffer the like troubles, He answers: before remission of sinnes these things be punishments sinnes, but after remission
they are trials and exercises of the iustified children of God. O when shall the lying Seminaries hearken to that of the Apostle.Heb. 12. 6. 7. Whom the Lord loueth he chasteneth, If you indure chastening, God offereth himselfe vnto you as to sonnes. Reuel. 3. 19. As manie as I loue I rebuke and chasten. Now if these corrections which be layed by our blessed God vpon his children, do not onely flow from that sweetest well of that loue, wherewith his Maiestie doth loue them in his blessed Sonne, but also by euident and sure pledges of that loue; can these corrections suffered by Gods children be possibly satisfactions for his iustice for sin? I charge thee therefore, ô my soule, that remaining within my bodie, thou countenance no sacrifice, besides that onely bloudie sacrifice, offered once onely vp by thy great hie Priest Iesus God,Esay 53. and man vpon the crosse vnto his Father for thee,2. Cor. 5. as thou desirest to be freed of the burthen of my sinnes, and of all punishment due to me for them. I charge thee that thou neuer lend thy eare to the sound of anie Purgatorie,Iohn 1. besides that cleane and cleansing pure bloud of that blessed Lambe of God who takes away the sinnes of the
world,1. Iohn 1. and whose bloud cleanseth thee from all sinne,Aug. in Epist. 171. euer crying with Augustine, Passio Domini pretium est orbis terrarum: The suffering of the Lord Iesus is the redemption of the world; and neuer forget to solace and cherish thy selfe in the middest of all extremities with that of Bernard: Bern. Passio tua Domine vltimum refugium est, singulare remedium; deficiente sapientia, iustitia non sufficiente, sanctitatis succumbentibus meritis: Thy passion ô Lord Iesus is my last refuge, my singular remedie, when my wisedome failes, when my righteousnesse is not sufficient; and when the merites of my holinesse do succumbe and are brought to nought, thy onely passion doth helpe me.

Oh, ô my soule, when shall the blindfold Papists (who partly avow that they do see, and who in this respect cannot but sinne grossely, and go on in sinne fearefully) beginne to perswade that they be blinde; to the end that through the tender mercies of God they may be freed from their sins? Could the Popish Seminaries (the sowers of Satans poyson, and people with the proud Pharisees, and who with,Esay 60 6. 3. the counterfet old idolatrous Iewes do offer swines bloud, and blesse an Idol)
begin to learne to discerne betwixt that great and onely Maiesticke high sacrificing Priest, Iesus, and their greedie and only mercenarie, slauish, sacrificing priest; would they beginne now at length (hauing stumbled so long at that lanterne of the blessed word of God,Marke the opposition which is betwixt Christ and his sacrifice and the Popish priest and his sacrifice and sinned against the light of their owne consciences,) to make a difference betwixt that bloudie sacrifice offered vp by Iesus, and these vnbloudie sacrifices now authorised and offered vp by them and their leaders, the Iesuites? O how farre would they adore the one, and abhorre the other! O with how swift feete would they runne towards the one, and flee from the other! Yea, ô how often would they present the one before the Lord their God, as that onely ransome which is onely able to satisfie his iustice for their monstrous debt of sinne, and repent before God and man thar euer they presented themselues before the other, which is nothing else but that odde abomination, wherby that debt of sinne is not onely kept ouer the head of man, but also fearefully augmented and increased, swearing solemnely neuer to countenance that Idoll. The heart of the
sacrificer Iesus, ô my soule, as Scripture witnesseth was the heart of a Lambe beyond all measure, gentle and pitifull, which neuer deuised any crueltie, which neuer consented to any crueltie. The mouth of that sacrificer Iesus was the truest mouth, the sweetest mouth that euer man spake with, neuer vttering any falsehood, neuer colouring, or couering anie crueltie to the preiudice or hurt of anie. The hand of that sacrificer Iesus, was the cleanest hand that euer man carried, the most liberall hand that euer man had, helping thousands, but neuer hurting one; sauing, and healing thousands, but neuer slaying or harming so much as one; albeit that sacrifice offred vp by this gentle, pitifull, true, sweet, liberall, and euer helping and sauing, but neuer harming or slaying sacrifice, was bloudie, yea was as it had bene nothing but all bloudie, his head, his side, his hands, his feete, being all couered therewith, so that not without cause some of the ancients could apply that of Isaiah to this blessed Sacrificer Iesus. Esay 61. 1. 2. 3. Who is this that cometh from Edom, with red garments from Bozrah? he is glorious in his apparell, and walketh in his great
strength, I speake in righteousnesse, and am mightie to saue? wherefore is thine apparell red, and thy garments like him that treadeth in the wine presse? I haue tread the wine presse alone, aud of all the people there was none with me. But, ô my soule, will not the Papist confesse (considering long and fearefull experience will testifie against him) that the heart of his sacrificing Priest is the heart of a lion, beyond measure fierce and false, deuising crueltie, approuing crueltie; that the mouth of his sacrificing Priest is the mouth of a diuell, hauing alwayes deceite & falsehood vnder his lips, and neuer so readily as when he bakes his false speeches with fearefull oathes. That the hand of his sacrificing Priest, is ye hand of one Bontcher and Burrio, delighting in nothing so much, as in the shedding of the bloud of Kings, Princes, and people, without any respect of sexe or age, albeit his sacrifice in the meane time (as he styles it) be vnbloudie. And here I would pray thee, ô my soule, (if thou be any way acquainted with the holy and iust God) to tell me ot thy God can possibly take vpon, or accept of that vnbloudie sacrifice which is offered vp by him who
hath a bloudie false heart, deuising crueltie and falshood? a bloudie tongue councelling and concealing, as he hath to do with God and his Saints, crueltie and falshood? yea, an hand executing crueltie and falshood? yea I must yet enquire of thee another thing, ô my soule, could that bloudie sacrifice offered vp by Iesus to God his Father for thee, haue possibly bene accepted of God, if his heart, his mouth, and hands, had bene such an heart, a mouth, and hands as the heart, mouth, and hands of the Papish priests be? No, no, ô my soule, had Christ heart bene such an heart, had Christs mouth bene such a mouth, had Christs hands bene such hands, as the heart, mouth, and hands of these Papish priests be, euen Christs sacrifice should haue bene reiected by God his Father. And therefore I heare Peter (fully abused by the Pope and his followers) telling me that I am not onely redeemed by the bloud of that Lambe Iesus,1. Pet. 1. 19. but of that Lambe Iesus; vndefiled, and without spot, cleane hearted, cleane tongued, cleane handed, and alwayes cleane. When I begin to thinke vpon this seriously, ô my soule, I cannot but wonder
who he is that hath conquired such a great cracke to the Papist priests in this our last age of the world, that an vnbloudie sacrifice comming from his bloudie, heart, mouth, and hands should be accepted of God, at whose hāds the old Iewes, Gods first borne, could finde no such fauour: for whe •• reade that first of Isaiah, I heare out God reiecting both the bloudie and vnbloudie sacrifices of the Iewes, to wit, their prayers and incest, and all because their hands were defiled with bloud, for speakes not our God by Isaiah thus:Isa. 1. 15. When you shall stretch out your hands I will hide my eyes from you, and though you make many prayers, I will not heare you, for your hands are full of bloud. Shall crueltie in the heart and in the hand of the counterfeit Iew, make that holy iust God of heauen refuse to accept from the hands of the Iewes these sacrifices, his Maiestie by his Law hath commanded? and shall this holy iust God accept of that sacrifice offered vp by that cruell heart, and bloudie hand of the Masse priest, which he neuer commanded, but which hath bene, is, and shall be, in despite of diuels and men, abhomination before his Maiestie, albeit he dare
dreame that his vnbloudie sacrifice smelled neuer so sweetly before God as when he hath come from the deuising or approuing of the slaughter of some few or moe, who do worship the true God of heauen, truly according to his will, and not as men would teach them? But it may be, ô my soule, that the priest his great God (the Pope I meane) who is clothed with a threefold diademe, as he who hath all power in heauen, and in earth, and in the hels, hath made him conceit that he hath procured this credit vnto him. Alwayes I am not ignorant, ô my soule, that the Papist Seminarie being challenged of crueltie, and taught cunningly by their leaders the Iebusites, will alledge and auow that they giue no counsell against the life of any, but of those who be the enemies of Christ, and that they neither giue counsell to slay any,The lesuits allegation to excuse their crueltie. neither do allow the slaughter of any, neither do slay any, but out of that loue which they carrie to Christ, and so to the end that by cutting off the enemies of Christ,This allegation is remoued and • roued they may build a glorious Church to his Maiestie. What if these allegations (plausibly to the Papist and his followers,Act, • 0. 28. but more then pernicious
in themselues) were examined by holy Scripture? Scripture tels me, that God by his owne bloud hath purchased a Church to himselfe: but Scripture told me neuer, that God would conquire a Church vnto himselfe by shedding the bloud of men and women, of Princes and subiects, old and yong. I heare our Maister indeed saying in the Gospell to his disciples:Ioh. 16. 2, The time shall come that whosoeuer killeth you, shall thinke he doth God good seruice: But I neuer heard him speake thus. The time shall come that whosoeuer killeth you shall do God good seruice: and knowest thou not, ô my soule, that there be great ods betwixt thought and deed, betwixt that which appeares to be, and that which is? Yea, knowest thou not that the Iewes thought that they were doing well, when they cryed out against our Maister, and stirred vp Pilat against him:Ioh. 18. 30. for can they not say: If he were not an euill doer we would not haue deliuered him vnto thee: I suspect not (but on speciall cause) that the blind Iesuite either hath neuer read, or neuer duely considered that 7. Chapter of the 2. of Samuel: was not Dauid a man according to the
heart of God? That bloud which he had shed, was it not shed by him on the speciall warrant of Gods command? (for as yet he had not slaine Vriah) and yet because he had dipped his hands in bloud, he cannot find libertie so much as to build an outward materiall temple to God; and shall that bloudie Burrio the Iesuite alledge, that he (hauing no warrant to shed that bloud which he sheds from God, yea hauing God and his conscience now and then pricking him for the shedding of it) can possibly erect a spirituall temple to God, building it vpon the meeke and strong rocke Iesus? I suspect that the Iesuite hath not as yet weighed that remembred by Matthew in his 26. Chap. there Peter seeing his Maister apprehended,Mat. 26. 51. 52. out of that loue he carries to him must draw his sword, and will shed bloud, for smites he not off the eare of the hie Priests seruant? Alwayes I thinke that his Maister said vnto him: Put vp thy sword in his place, for he that taketh the sword shall perish with the sword. O bloudie Iesuite, beside Matthew, I heare Iesus commanding Peter to put vp his sword in the place, but where heardest thou blessed Iesus charging thee
to draw thy sword? O when shall that of the Apostle be thought vpon by these blind leading Papists, and blind led Papists?2. Thess. 2. 11. 12. Because they receiued not the loue of the truth that they might be saued, therefore God shall send them strong delusions, that they shall beleeue lies, tht all they might be damned which beleeued not the truth, but had pleasure in vnrighteousnesse. O when shall the bloudie Caines of this time find grace to haue themselues wakened by that ancient watch-word: Coedi Christianorum proprium est, coedere autem Christianos, Pilati, & Caiaphae officia sunt. It is proper to Christians to be slaine, but it is the office of Caiaphas and Pilat to slay Christians. I wonder, if Bernard were liuing now, how he would take the bloud of the Saints of God, shed daily by the Popes command and allowance like water; who tooke so hardly with one Thomas a Prior at Paris, murthered in his time, for preaching against the corruption of Churchmen? for writes he not thus to the Pope touching that matter:Bern. ep. 158. Fera pessima quae deuorauit Ioseph, canum nostr • rum importunitatem non ferens, ad vestrae defensionis auxilium dicitur confugisse, in quantum misera
devenit amentiam; vt vaga, & profuga, & tremens super terram illic potissimum fugam inierit, vbi plus timere oportuit. Scelestissime, tu summae aequitatis sedem, speluncāputas esse latronum, aut cubile leonum? That beast which deuoured Ioseph, who could not suffer the vilenesse and wickednesse of our dogs, is said to haue fled to the helpe of your maintenance. O to what a madnesse hath that wretch come, that wandering and driuen from his owne countrey, and shaking vpon the earth through feare, he should take his flight specially to that place, where he should haue specially feared in great measure. O thou most wicked man, thinkest thou the chaire of greatest equitie to be a denne of theeues, or a cage of Lyons? Sure I am were Bernard liuing, he would imploy the whole strength of his penne against the Iesuites, drawing them by reason of their vncouth falshood, and more then barbarous crueltie within the compasse of vile heretickes: for could he not long ago, drawing his penne against the heretickes of his time, write thus: Indixere (vt dicitur) latebras sibi, Ber. ser. 65. firmauerunt sermonem nequam, iura periura; secretum prodere noli; alias ne tenuiter quidem iurare vllatenus acquiescunt, propter illud in Euangelio,
ne iuretis, ne
que per coelum, neque per terram. O stulti, & tardi corde, repleti pharisaico spiritu, liquentes culicem, & camelum glutientes, iurare licet & periurare licet. They haue promised vnto themselues (as it is said) starting holes, so that they shall not be seene; they haue setled a wicked speech among themselues, saying one to another; sweare, forsweare; and so make one oath, breake one oath; alwayes reueale not our secret: and yet otherwise they will no wayes consent to sweare so much as slenderly; because of that they reade in the Gospell, Sweare not at all, neither by the heauen nor by the earth. O fooles and slow of heart, filled with a Pharisaicall spirit, straining out a gnat and swallowing a camell. It is not lothsome to me to sweare, and yet is lothsome to me to sweare falsly, and so to forsweare my selfe. O when shall the cruell hearted, the lying tongued, and the bloudie handed Iesuite leaue off to wearie that blessed holy God of heauen, and to deceiue his poore babes with that his vnbloudie sacrifice, neuer knowne to God, neuer commanded by his Sonne,The sacrifice all Ministers should offer to God. and begin to take pleasure to sacrifice vnto God, that holy sacrifice (that Apostle who communicated not with flesh and bloud) but who
was taught of God what to do, to sacrifice to his Maiestie? Hearest thou not, ô my soule, that the Apostle saith to thee? I haue somwhat boldly after a sort written vnto you, as one that putteth you in rememberance through the grace that is giuen me of God, Rom. 15. 15. 16. that I should be the Minister of Iesus Christ towards the Gentiles, ministring the Gospell of God, that the offering vp of the Gentiles might be acceptable, being sanctified by the holy Ghost. Chrysostome writing vpon these words will haue the whole Apostolicke priesthood to consist in preaching, saying in the person of Paul, Ipsum enim mihi sacerdotitium est praedicare & Euangelizare, hanc offero hostiam. My priesthood is to preach and to sound the euangell; this offering I offer; And going on in the explication of the seuerall parts of this metaphor for the better vnderstanding of this sacrifice offered vp by the Apostle he tells vs the sword whereby he did slay the sacrifice offered vp by him to God was the Euangell; that the art of sacrificing, was the preaching of the Euangell; that the fire whereby the sacrifice was burnt, was the faith of God; that the sacrifice sacrificed
by him, was the Gentiles; that the Priests sacrificing this sacrifice, was the Apostles sent of God to this effect. Had these monsters sent from Rome these manie yeares by gaine, bene exercised about the sacrificing of such sacrifices, drawing of the sword, and kindling of this fire here remembred by Paul, ô what a world of bloud of soules of men, of womē, of yong, of old should haue bene spared, which hath bene by their directions, & allowāce spilt: yea, ô what a world of bloud of soules of men, of women, of old, & yong; who perished through their default withdrawne by them from that bloudie propitiatorie sacrifice offered vp by Iesus, and making them to doate after their vnbloudie sacrifice of the Masse, which can no wayes impaire but alwayes augment their debt and dutie. Here leauing their indured monsters to their owne induring maisters, and reuerincing the dispensation of that wise God whose iudgemeuts are vnsearchable, and his wayes past finding out,Igna Epist. 6. ad Phil. we must remember that of Ignatius: Quemadmodum pseudoprophetae & pseudoapostoli vnum & eundem spiritum fallacem, & populi seductorem acceperunt; sic prophetae &
Apostoli vnum & eundem spiritum, sanctum, bonum, eximium, verum, & doctorem rectū acceperunt à Deo per Iesum Christum. As the false prophets and apostles receiued anie euill spirit, to deceiue the people: So the true Prophets and Apostles receiue from God through Iesus Christ, and his holy spirit, the good, excellent, true, teacher of righteousnesse.

div.head: THE FIFTH ROBBER is the Popish Seminarie, subtily stealing from the babes of God that royall, and sweet smelling garment of Christ his righteousnesse put on by faith; and obtruding to them that rotten ragge of iustification by their owne workes.
div.p:
EVerie proud man is odious before God, ô my soule, but specially the proud hypocrite, who looking vnto man, his brother, is not ashamed to crie out: Stand apart, Esay 66. 5. come not neere me, for I am holier then thou: O God, I thanke thee that I am not as other men, Luke 11. 12. extortioners, vniust, adulterers, or euen as this Publican; I fast twice in
the weeke, I will giue the tyth of all that euer I possesse. For is not this testimonie giuen to the one?Esay. 65. 5. These are as smokes in my wrath, and a fire that burneth all day; and this to the other by our God who knoweth all Iustifiers of themselues, and abhorres them:Luk. 18. 14. but this man went home vniustified. Could these blinding Robbers, and proud Pharisees the Papists of this our age see this, ô my soule, would they not begin to curse the first inuenters, and venters of that hellish doctrine of Iustification by workes and aduancing of mans merits?The inuē ters of Iustification by workes are to be cursed. To my iudgment, there is not a Papist liuing this day, yea, that there was neuer a Papist, who liued before these our dayes, who is or was sanctified in a higher measure, or made instruments of such good workes, as Moses that faithfull seruant of God was, louing his God with a zelous loue, louing Gods people with a laborious loue; yea, what Papist could euer haue alledged, or can this day alledge, that he was or is more crucified to the world; or had, or hath the world more crucified to him, then Moses had it? for cannot Moses (through the grace of God) renounce all the honours, riches, and
pleasures of the land of Egypt, and content (esteeming the rebuke of Christ, his onely riches, honour, and pleasure) to affliction • , yea most sharpe long affliction, with, and for Gods people.
