And yet when this great God drawes neare this same Moses, Moses must be content to heare this said to him:Exod. 3. 5. Come not hither, put thy shoes off thy feete, for the place where thou standest is holy ground. What Papist can with a conscience, or countenance aduance himselfe aboue Ioshua, that faithfull seruant of God? and yet when that mightie holy God draweth neare to him, Ioshua must heare that said to him which was said to Moses before him:Iosua 5. 15. Lose thy shoes off thy feete, for the place where thou standest is holy. What if the Papist could compare that which he may reade by Moses in the 34. of Exodus, and by Paul in the 4. of the Romanes, with that (a alas) he hath brought to his eares by the smooth flattering tongues of his lying Seminaries and to his eyes by the poysoning volums of his deceiuing teachers? would he not be ashamed before God to alledge anie Iustification by workes, or to obtrude vnto his Maiesties owne merites? When I
reade the 34. of Exodus, I first see Moses comming downe from the mount Sinai where he had stayed 40. dayes talking with his God: Secondly, I see the skum of Moses face shining so brightly after that God had talked with him, that not the children of Israel only, but Aaron also is affrayed to come neare him; whereupon Moses was compelled to couer his face with a vaile when he spake to them, albeit when Moses came before the Lord to speake to his Maiestie,Exod. 34. 29. 31. 32. 33. 34. 35. he tooke off the couering from his face. When I reade the 4. to the Romanes, I heare Paul confessing that Abraham looking vnto man might haue maintained Iustification by workes, but that he looking vnto God, behoued to renounce all such Iustification, fleeing by faith to the free mercie of God onely, remitting him all his sinnes to his euerlasting blessednesse in his blessed Sonne: one man compared with another man, and comparing before him, may appeare to shine gloriously; but if a man could bring himselfe before his God, all his shining glorie should proue obscure vanitie, yea blacke like the tent of Kedar. What wonder that the
Papist hath not learned this, for will he search Scripture? dare he attempt to search Scripture, albeit that Scripture be that onely true looking-glasse in the which he may see his God, he may see himselfe? And which is to be lamented, ô my soule, can he ceasse to lend his eare, yea wholely to sell himselfe ouer to lying mans vaine traditions, which makes white appeare to be blacke, and blacke appeare to be white; which makes good appeare to be euill, and euill appeare to be good.1. Cor. 4. 4. Shall Paul say I know nothing by my selfe,Iob 39. 37. 38. & 42. 5. 6. Yet I am not thereby iustified? yea, shall Iob who could talke freely and largely before his friends, lay his hand vpon his mouth, repent in dust and ashes when he is drawne before his God? And dare the Papist comming before God boast himselfe, or dreame that he shineth in Gods eyes to the Iustification of himselfe? Bernard reprouing the dead blindnesse of his time could say: Nec talia sunt hominum merita, vt propter ea vita aeterna debeatur ex iure, vt Deus aliquam iniuriam faceret nisi eam donaret. Nam vt taceā quod merita omnia dona Dei sunt, & it a homo propter ipsa Deo debitor est, magis quā Deus
homini. Quid sunt merita omnia ad tantam gloriam? denique quis melior est Propheta, cui Dominus ipse tam insigne testimoniū perhibet dicens, virum inueni secundum cor meum? Veruntamen ipse Propheta necesse habuit dicere ne intres in iudicium cum seruo tuo Domine. The merites of men be not such that by anie law euerlasting life can be due vnto them or as if God should do any wrong vnlesse he recompensed them with eternall life: for besides this which I will passe with silence, that all merites of man are the gifts of God, so that a man for them is rather a debtor to God, then God a debtor to him; what proportion possibly can there be betwixt mans merits and that great weight of glorie which is layed vp in heauen? And to conclude, what is man better then that Prophet, to whō God gaue so notable a testimonie saying: I haue found a man according to my owne heart, Psal 143. 12 & yet this same Prophet behoued to say: O Lord enter not into iudgement with thy seruant, for in thy sight shall none that liueth be iustified. No works can iustifie. Must thou not know, ô my soule, y• all workes which be done by man here, be either euill workes repugnant to Gods Law, and forbidden of God; or good workes agreeable to his Law and commandement, yea,
commanded by him. Euery man of himselfe can easily do euill workes, which be condemned and forbidden of God: (for Man drinketh iniquitie like water; Iob 15. 16. yea euen the iust man falleth seuen times a day) and do grosly infect and defile man.Pro. 64. 12. Good works againe commanded and commended by God can no man of himselfe possibly do; for hearest thou not, ô my soule, the Spirit speaking thus to thee: We are dead in sinnes and trespasses: Ephes. 2. 1. Of our selues we are not sufficient to thinke any thing as of our selues, 2. Cor. 3. 5. but our sufficiencie is of God. Hearest thou not thy Sauiour (who can deceiue none) saying to thee:Ioh. 15. 5. Without me ye can do nothing. Yea speakes not Paul thus: We are Gods workmanship created in Christ Iesus vnto good workes, Ephes. 2. 10 which God hath ordained that we should walke in them. And will he not resolue the Philippians thus? It is God which worketh in you both the will and the deed of his good pleasure. Phil. 2. 13. Now I must tell thee, ô my soule, that all men, euen the dearest Saints and seruants of God, are so defiled with sinne, that whensoeuer our God by his Spirit worketh any good worke in them, and by them, they cannot but (by that sea of filth which alwayes remaines
in them) defile that good worke of God, and make it abhominable in his eyes, if in iustice he would looke vpon it. And therfore euen the Saints and seruants of God knowing this, when they are made instruments of good workes, can crie out:Iob 14. 4. Who can bring a cleane thing out of vncleannesse? there is not one. Yea treading the pathes of that Euangelicall royall Prophet Isaiah, they will not be ashamed thus to blesse themselues, to the end they may honour their God:Isa 64. 6. We haue all bene as an vncleane thing, and all our righteousnesse as filthie clouts. This moued Augustine to say:Aug. ep. 106 Opera ex gratia, non ex operibus gratia; quoniam fides quae per dilectionem operatur, nihil operatur, nisi ipsa dilectio Dei diffundatur in cordibus nostris per spiritum sanctum, qui datus est nobis; nec ipsa fides esset in nobis, nisi Deus vnicuique partiretur mensuram fidei. Good workes are of grace, and not grace of good workes; because faith which worketh by charitie, could worke nothing vnlesse the loue of God were shed abroad in our hearts, by the holy Ghost which is giuen to vs; yea faith could not be wrought in vs, vnlesse our God imparted to euery one of vs a measure of faith. Yea, this moued him to say:
Cum malus sum, nihil aliud est confiteri tibi quam displiceri mihi; cum vero pius, nihil aliud est confiteritibi quam hoc non tribuere mihi quoniam tu Domine benedicis iustum, sed prius cum iustificas impium. When I am wicked, offending thee, I cannot otherwayes confesse my selfe to thee, but being displeased with my selfe for grieuing of thee: when I am vpright, doing good, I cannot better confesse my selfe to thee, then by not challenging the doing of that good to my selfe, because thou, O Lord, doest blesse the iust man, and yet before that, thou iustifiest him being vniust and without God. This moued him also to hold this for a firme ground: Cum Deus remunerat opera nostra, coronat in nobis dona sua. While our God rewards our workes, he crownes in vs his owne gifts. For as Bernard, who liued in a corrupt time long after Augustine, saith, Gratia non solum peccata lauat, sed etiam merita donat. The grace of God not onely washeth vs from sinne, but gifteth vs also with merit. Iustifiers of themselues are no sons to God but mercenary slaues. Alwayes here led by Scripture I must say more to thee, ô my soule, whosoeuer dare attempt to thinke or alledge, that he should onely refraine his hands from euill, walking before God and among men holily, to the end that
thereby he may merit eternall life at the hands of God, cannot possibly carrie the honest heart of a louing sonne, nor the cleane hand of an vpright seruant, but doth prooue himselfe to be a very mercenarie slaue worthie to be put out of Gods doores; for as God loued vs freely, so he will be freely loued of vs. This moued our wisest Maister, whose words neuer sauored Popish doctrine, thus to direct his disciples:Luk. 17. 10. When ye haue done all these things which are commanded you, say we are vnprofitable seruants, we haue done that which was our dutie to do. The sense hereof moued Augustine sweetly to say: Hoc affectu & desiderio colendus est Deus, vt sui cultus ipse sit merces. August. ep. 120. Nam qui Deum ideo colit, vt aliud magis quam ipsum promereatur, non Deum colit, sed illud quod assequi concupscit. Our God is with this affection and earnest desire of heart to be worshipped by vs, that he himselfe may be the reward of that worship wherewith we worship him: For whosoeuer worships God, to the effect that thereby he may merit to himselfe some other thing beside God, worships not God, but that other thing which he desires to obtaine at his hands. The sense whereof moued him, toning his sweete song with
a loud voice, to crie out: Tunc enim recte, tunc iuste, tunc pie fit; cum opus bonum in eius laudem fit, cuius gratia donatur vt fiat. Then a good worke is done rightly, iustly, and holily; when it is done for the glorie and praise of his name, whose fauour and grace made the doer of it able to do it. In Ioan. tract. 3. And againe. Si gratiam ideo Deus tibi dedit quia gratis dedit, gratis ama; noli ad praemium diligere Deum, ipse sit praemium tibi. If God hath giuen grace to thee because he hath giuen it freely, see that thou loue thy God freely, loue not thy God for any reward, let God himselfe be thy reward to thee. It was holily and couragiously said by the three children vnto Nebuchadnezzar, ô my soule, We are not carefull to answer thee in this matter; Dan. 3. 16. 17. 18. behold our God whom we serue is able to deliuer vs from the hote fierie fornace, and he will deliuer vs out of thy hands ô King. But if not (marke this my soule, I pray thee) be it knowne to thee, ô King, that we will not serue thy gods, nor worship the golden image which thou hast set vp. Resoluing hereby Nebuchadnezzar, albeit they should be left by their blessed onely true God to be deuoured by the burning flames of his fornace, yet they would not ceasse to worship God, or appeare
to regard his idoll. O when shall the selfe iustifying Papist begin to take some paines to know God, and his owne heart? for could he know these two, he would seeke for some secret place with Peter, there to weepe bitterly that euer he inuented or vented, or professed and maintained, that damnable poysoning leauen of iustification by workes, considering that great and onely true teacher of our soules hath said:Luk. 16. 15. Ye are they which iustifie your selues before men, but God knoweth your hearts, for that which is highly esteemed among men is an abhomination in the sight of God. Ignorance the mother of the vile doctrine of humane merit. Ignorance then, ô my soule, yea, most grosse ignorance (as thou mayest see) hath rikled vp that sandie bray of the Romane synagogue, now running speedily by its owne force to a decay; and fearefull vncouth ignorance hath made the blind Papist to inuent, and vent that mischieuous doctrine of mans merits.He who would merit must do 3. things. For must not euen the simplest man confesse, that whosoeuer would merit any thing by his working at the hands of God must do three things: for first, that which he doeth, he must do it of himselfe, and by himselfe; for if he do it by the grace and
strength of another, that other merits and not he.Ioh. 15. Now if Christ be true, no man can do any thing which is good but him. And if Paul be not deceiued, no man doing any thing by the grace of God can but with shame boast himselfe of y• which h •
doeth.1. Cor. 4. Secondly, that which the meriting man doth, must be done of meere good will, and not of dutie; for if it be done by the force of any obligation binding him thereunto, the doer cannot possibly merit any thing by the doing of it: and yet I hope the Papist (if he haue not both cauterised his conscience, and seared his face with a brasen countenance) will blush to alledge that he is not bound to do all, and more then possibly he can do, and when he hath done it, that he cannot merit thereby, if he could heare the voice of God and beleeue it, as the voice of him who would be his Father and shepheard: Ishow mercie vnto thousands of them that loue me, Ezod. 26. and keepe my Commandements. Thirdly, that worke which is done by a man to the end that he may merit by it, must be proportionable, and answerable to that reward a man expects for the doing of it. Now what man liuing here can
possibly do or suffer that which can be answerable to the worth and excellent valew of that eternall life layed vp in heauen? Paul saw that it was a greater gift to suffer for Christ, then to beleeue in Christ: and therefore could speake touching the Philippians thus:Phil. 1. 29. Vnto you it is giuen for Christ, that not onely ye should beleeue in him, but also suffer for his sake. And yet that same Paul writing to the Romanes can say:Rom. 8. 18. I account that the afflictions of this present time are not worthie of the glorie that shall be shewed vnto vs. And so from my heart I pray God make the hautie Papist at length subscribe from his heart and with his hand vnto that heauenly poesie:
Datua, sed quae non debes, proportio constet,
Haud aliter meritum dixeris esse tuum.
Giue those things which be thine owne, but which thou art no wayes bound to giue; let there be a proportion betwixt the gift and the reward, otherwise alledge not that thou hast any merit. Conclude then, ô my soule, if thou wouldst appeare iust before that onely iust Iudge, as I saiah concludeth: We haue all bene as an vncleane thing, Isa. 64. 6. and all our righteousnesse as filthie clouts; as Paul concludeth: I know nothing
by my selfe, 1. Cor. 4. 1. yet I am not thereby iustified. As Bernard concludeth, taught by the Spirit, and led by the Scripture long ago. Sufficit mihi ad omnem iustitiam, Ber. serm. Cant. 23. solum habere propitium eum, cui soli peccaus; non peccare Dei iustitia est, hominis iustitia Dei indulgentia. It suffices me for my whole and perfect righteousnesse, to haue him mercifull vnto me, against whom I haue sinned. Gods righteousnesse is not to sinne, mans righteousnesse is Gods indulgence and free pardon. And therefore ô how neatly, how truly, how pretily was it said: Dare non dignis res mage digna Deo est. It is a thing most worthie of our God, who is goodnesse, mercie, liberalitie it selfe, to giue euer grace and glorie vnto those who being vnworthy of themselues merit confusion and eternall death.

div.head: THE SIXTH ROBBER IS the Popish Seminarie, with a shamelesse face and bloudie hand, stealing from the child of God the mediation and intercession of that sole Mediator God and man, euen the Man Christ Iesus, & putting in his hands the intercession of Saints.
div.p:
TRue sauing prayer,Sauing prayer is a royall wise ambassadour. ô my soule, may iustly be styled, that royall ambassadour, prudent and couragious, who lodging alwayes in a cleane cabinate, is directed from that greatest king, towards that greatest monarch, and who can no wayes vpon anie condition be moued to stay from iourneying forwards till he come before him, to whom he was sent; discharging that commission which he carrieth in his bosome: and besides him neither to minion, nor courtiour, nor anie of his subiects whatsoeuer. Tell me, ô my soule, can anie in heauen, anie vnder heauen, teach thee to pray for thy saluation, besides that great King, euen the spirit of the Father, and of his dearest Sonne? and therefore that great teacher of the Gentiles,Rom. 8. 26. can resolue thee thus: The spirit helpeth our infirmities, for we know not what to pray as we ought, but the spirit it selfe makes requests for vs with sighes that cannot be expressed. This ambassadour of prayer comming from the spirit, cannot lodge but in the quickned soule, and reneued heart of Gods child. Reprobates I confesse may possesse manie delicates, but this delicate of sauing prayer they cannot haue, and
therefore the said great teacher of the Gentiles, can marrie, as it were, Prayer & Saluation, after an inseperable manner, together saying:Rom. 10. 13. Whosoeuer calleth vpon the name of the Lord (to wit, being led by the spirit of adoption, the onely author of heauenly supplication) shall be saued. Sauing prayer besides this is so prudent, and couragious that being sent by the spirit, from the honest heart of Gods renued child, towards that onely superexcellent monarch God his Father, it will not giue so much as a looke, let by a God-speed (as it were) to anie Angel, to anie Saint in heauen, vnto anie man in earth, (being so directed by that spirit by whom it was sent) till it come before that great Maiestie of the God of heauen, with whom onely it hath bene, & there in his bosome poured forth it selfe. O my soule, art thou not thus charged by God the Father, Call vpon me in the day of thy trouble. Psal. 50 15. Art thou not thus charged by God thy Sauiour?Mat. 6. 9. when ye pray pray thus. Our father which art in heauen? art thou not thus charged by God thy comforter, and keeper.Iames 1. 5. If anie aske wisedome, let him aske it of God. Search, search, ô my soule, the whole
old Testament, the whole new Testament and trie if thou there mayest gather, either with a precept directing thee to pray to any in heauen, or vnder heauen, besides thy God? or with anie, promise that if thou prayest vnto anie beside his Maiestie, thou shalt speed? or lastly, with any practise, shewing thee that euer any of Gods children euer sent vp their prayers to any, beside that blessed God in whom they beleeued.Popish superstitious bablings be no prayers. Vnderstand, vnderstand, ô my soule, that the ignorant profane bablings of the blind superstious Papists, can be no prayers indited by the blessed Spirit of God; but windie, foolish, effectlesse words, comming from their owne deceiued braines and fond imaginations; for if they come from Gods Spirit, they would be directed vnto God onely.The Papist police in aduancing his lying doctrine of inuocation of Saints. But since they be drawne vp vnto creatures, they cannot come from the true Spirit of that creator blessed for euermore, but from the lying spirit of base cursed creatures. The blind bloudie restlesse Seminarie compassing the earth to and fro with Satan, shewing alwayes where he commeth (any occasion being offered to him) he is poysoned, and poysoning
people, either to impede the receiuing, or to hinder the grouth of the good wheate of Gods word; to the end that he may perswade men and women of all rankes, euen with greedinesse, to embrace his lying doctrine, touching the inuocation of Saints: hath verie highly heretofore, and doth still, verie farre aduance that foolish comparison taken from the courts of earthly Princes; and this comparison he hath hatched, to the end he may the more subtily aduance the grandour & wealth of that vile court of Rome and with this draw away, not onely poore simple people from being truly courteours, with that King of glorie blessed for euer; but also to stirre them vp (albeit he abhorreth to confesse this) to make themselues grosse and auowed traitors against his Maiestie.While the Papist cō pares Gods kingdome vnto a court, they trauell to m • ke vs traitors to the king of that court. O shamelesse Papist is not this thy fond allegance! As subiects (considering the grandor of their Princes, and their owne basenesse) are accustomed to go to their kings by courteours and noble men. So the children of God, considering the excellencie of that Maiestie wherewith their God is clothed, being sensible in the meane time of their owne vilenesse
by reason of these sinnes wherewith they are clogged, should not attempt to go to their God, but by these Saints which are in heauen. Hadst thou, ô effronted Papist, hearkened vnto yt answer, (now neare by twelfe hundred yeares ago) giuen to this purpose,Ambr. on Rom. 8. by that famous Bishop of worthie memorie, Ambrose: thou wouldest haue bene affrayed from receiuing gredily without any shew or reason, that effectlesse comparison; and from keeping it so pertenatiously, euen to this day, without any kind of shame? for this cause men and women are moued to go to kings, by noble men and courteours; because kings be but men, and know not to whom they should commit the gouernment of their countrey: but while a man hath to do with his God, from whom nothing can be hidde (for all men are knowne by him) we haue neede of no such mediator, but of a deuout humble holy heart: for whensoeuer such an heart shall speake, God shall louingly answer it. But deceiued, and deceiuing Seminarie! to what purpose will this thy comparison serue thee in that countrey where the king with whom thou hast to do, hath by a speciall Edict,
vnder his great seale and publicke proclamation raised thereupon, authorised his eldest Sonne, to be the onely mediator, by whom his subiects great and small, any wayes offending him, or standing in neede of any thing at his hands, should haue recourse vnto him; discharging them herewith vnder the highest paine, to make any suite by the mediation of any other whatsoeuer? Secondly, if the Prince the Kings eldest sonne, being thus authorised by his father, haue by his publicke proclamation (hauing receiued from his father speciall warrant so to do) certified all his fathers subiects, that none of them possibly can come to him but by him? Thlrdly, if the Lords of the Kings secret counsell, being certified of the truth hereof, would beside this (being commanded by the King and his sonne) charge all the subiects to come to the Kings sonne, yea, to his sonne onely, whensoeuer they haue to do with the King his father. Now, ô blind bold Seminarie, I appeale thy conscience, vnlesse thou hast layed aside all conscience, and made that whore of Babell thy God, if thou be acquainted with that voyce which was sounded from
the heauens, that day in the which that blessed sole Sauiour of the world was baptized?Mat. 3. 17. This is my welbeloued Sonne in whom I am well pleased. Yea, hearest thou not this voyce sounded ouer againe with an addition, that day in the which that holy one was transfigured:Mat. 17. 6. This is my welbeloued Sonne in whom I am well pleased heare him. O Seminarie, wilt thou not heare the sonne saying to thee?Iohn 14. 6. I am the way, the verity, & the life, no man comes to the Father, but by me. Hearest thou him not thus secretly inuiting thee to come directly to him?Mat. 11. 28. Come vnto me all ye which are wearie and laden, and I will ease you. Yea, ô Seminarie possessed with a deafe diuell, when God speaketh to thee by his word: wilt thou not heare that great Apostle Paul, who was well acquainted with the whole counsell of God saving vnto thee? There is one God and one Mediator betwixt God and man, euen the man Christ Iesus. Bernard from his heart, subioyning with his hand vnto this sounded by Saint Paul, could say:1. Tim. 2. 5 Ber. ser. in cant. 48. Vnus est vitae dator, vnus mediator Dei & hominum, homo Christus Iesus, qui dicit sponsae suae: Salus tua ego sum. There is one giuer of life, and one mediator betwixt
God and man, the man Christ Iesus: who saith vnto his spouse, I am thy saluation. Sure I am, were old Christome aliue, he would as farre condemne the auowed profane mad folly of the superstitious Papist in this point, as he commanded the holy wisedome of that sincere woman, whose daughter was possessed with a diuell: for speakes he not thus touching her? Behold the wisedome of the woman, Chrysost de Cana. saith he, she prayeth not to Iames, she maketh not her supplication to Iohn, she goeth not to Peter, neither respecteth she the companie of the Apostles, requiring helpe of any of them, but in stead of them all, (taking happily vnfained repentance for her companion,) she goeth directly forward to blessed Iesus, that onely well which was able to yeeld out that sweet water which she thristed for. Amb. in lib. Isak. Ambrose saw this while he could say: Christus est os nostrum, per quod patri loquimur; oculus noster, per quem patrem videmus; dextra nostra, per quam patri nos offerimus; quo nisi intercedente, nec nobis nec sanctis omnibus quicquam cum Deo est. Christ is our mouth by the which we speake to the father; our eyes by the which we see the father; our right hand, by the which we offer our selues to the father:
without whose intercession, neither we, nor any of the Saints haue any interesse in, or accesse to, God. And therefore what wonder that Irenaeus before Ambrose writeth thus:Iren. lib. 2. cap. 57. Non rationibus angelicis fiat aliquid, nec aliqua praua curiositate; sed mundae & purae orationes dirigantur ad Dominum, quia omnia fecit, & nomen Domini nostri Iesu Christi, cuius nomen omnia praestat, & curat, non autem alterius cuiusquam. Let nothing be done by the counsels of Angels, or through any wicked curiositie; but let our cleane and pure prayers be directed to that God who made all things, and to the name of our Lord Iesus Christ, whose name helpes and cures all things, and not to the name of any other whatsoeuer. But will the restlesse Seminarie rest, ô my soule, when these things are brought from the very mouth of God vnto his eares? no, no, for the tricking Seminarie who can cunningly catch simple soules by his entrapping subtilties, will confesse, that blessed Iesus that onely Son of that great King, is the onely Mediator of reconciliation betwixt God and man; but with this he will maintaine, that there be other Mediatours of intercession besides him, who may make and do make request vnto God
for vs. Spare not, spare not, ô my soule, to say vnto the shamelesse pert Seminarie when he speaketh thus, Auoide Satan: as one sent ou • by that craftie foxe, and cruell dragon, first by his subtiltie to snare thee, and then by his crueltie to slay thee; demanding him euen from a strong heart and with a good countenance thus: O Seminarie, out of what booke, out of whose mouth, learnedst thou to put a difference betwixt the Mediatour of reconciliation and intercession?None can be the Mediatour of intercessiō but who is the Mediatour of reconciliatiō. for out of Gods Booke, out of Gods mouth, speaking to thee by Scripture, thou learnedst it neuer; albeit no booke besides Gods booke, no mouth besides Gods mouth, must in this point informe thee: for telleth not Gods booke me, and so Gods mouth, first, that we haue no mediatour who can possibly intercede for vs at the hands of our God, but that mediatour who hath reconciled vs to our God, for be not these the words of Paul: There is one God and one Mediatour betwixt God and man, the man Christ Iesus. If Paul had spoken thus, There is one mediatour betwixt God and man, the man Christ Iesus; he had spoken enough to conuince the lying Seminarie, but he will say more,
euen this: There is one God and one Mediator betwixt God and man, the man Christ Iesus, to make the Seminarie ashamed (if he could be) of his subtiltie; for hereby he would tell thee, ô my soule, that as there is one onely true God, and no waies in any respect another, euen the Father, Sonne, and holy Ghost; so there is onely one true Mediator, and in no respect another. Secondly, telleth not Gods booke, and so Gods mouth me, that this Iesus Christ could not possibly haue bene a Mediatour of intercession for vs, praying to God for vs, vnlesse he had bene a Mediatour of reconciliation for vs, by his bloudie sacrifice, satisfying his Fathers iustice for our sinnes. O vile Seminarie, darest thou giue that great disciple (whom Iesus loued, and who lay in Iesus bosome) the lye? for speakes he not thus. If anie man sinne, 1. Ioh. 2. 1. 2 we haue an Aduocate with the Father, Iesus Christ the Iust, and he is the reconciliation for our sinnes. Thus ioyntly ioyning Christs intercession and reconciliation together; and from his reconciliation of vs, proouing that he hath onely right to intercede for vs; for if he had not reconciled vs, he could no wayes
haue any right to pray for vs, neither durst we haue attempted to haue had any recourse to him as to our Mediatour; yea, which is more ô my soule, if he had not bene our onely Reconciler, he could not haue bene our Mediatour at all. Augustine writing vpon this place out of the sense hereof speaketh thus: Ioannes non dixit aduocatum habetis sed habemus, August. nec me habetis (dixit) sed Christum posuit nonse, maluit se ponere in numero peccatorum, vt haberet Aduocatum Christum, quam ponere se pro Christo aduocatum, & inueniri inter damnandos superbos fratres. Iesum Christum ipsum habemus aduocatum ad patrem, ipse est propitiatio peccatorum nostrorum; hoc qui tenuit, haeresin non facit. Inde enim facta sunt schismata, cum dicunt homines nos iusti sumus, nos sanctificamus immundos, nos iusti ficamus impios, nos petimus, nos impetramus. Iohn said not ye haue an Aduocate, but we; neither said he, ye haue me, but putting Christ for our aduocate not himself; for he had rather haue put himselfe amongst the number of sinners, to the end he might haue Christ for his Aduocate, then to make himselfe aduocate in Christs stead, and so in the end to be found among those proud brethren who shall be damned.
We haue Iesus Christ the iust himselfe for our Aduocate with the Father, he is a propitiation for our sinnes, whosoeuer holds this maintaines no heresie, makes no schisme; for schismes proceed of this, when men say, we are iust, we sanctifie the vncleane, we iustifie the wicked, we pray, we obtaine. O when shall the blind Popish Seminarie thinke and write as honorably of that excellent worke of mediation, as Tertullian thought and wrote of it, for sees he it not to be so excellent, that he can find neither Angell nor man any wayes fit for it? yea, that he must affirme that none can be mediatour betwixt God and man but he who was God. And therefore prouing Christ to be God amongst other arguments he vseth this:Tert. in lib. de Trin. Cur homo in orationibus inuocatur, cum inuocatio hominis ad praestandam salutem inefficax iudicetur? cur spes in illo ponitur cum spes in homine maledicta referatur? Wherefore is man called vpon in our prayers, seeing the calling vpon man for the obtaining of saluation must be thought altogether ineffectuall? Wherefore do men trust in him, seeing the confidence which is put in man is cursed? Augustine after Tertullian saw this also, when he said: Quem i • uenirem qui me
reconciliaret tibi?Aug lib. 10. conf. cap. 42. an eundem fuit mihi ad Angelos, qua prece, quibus sacramentis? multi conantes ad teredire, neque per seipsos valentes sicut audio, tentauerunt hos, & inciderunt in desiderium curiosarum visionum, & digni habiti sunt illusionibus. Mediator autem inter Deum & homines, oporteret vt haberet aliquid simile Deo, aliqu • d simile hominibus; ne in vtroque similis hominibus, longe esset à Deo, aut in vtroque similis Deo, longe esset ab hominibus. Whom could I finde who was able to reconcile me to thee? should I haue gone to the Angels, by what prayer, by what allegation? many pressing to returne to thee, and not being able by themselues, as I heare, haue assayed to do this, and haue fallen headlong in the loue of curious visions, and haue bene thought worthie of mocking and scorning: for it behoued that he who should be Mediatour betwixt God and man, should haue some thing like vnto God, and some thing like vnto man; lest being in euery thing like vnto man, he should haue bene farre from God, or lest being in euery thing like vnto God he should haue bene farre from man: and so be no mediatour. I wonder if euer the Papist Seminarie read that ancient Father Epiphanius in his 74. heresie, where by
nine strong arguments he proues that the Virgin Marie should haue no prayer made to her, and so be vsed as a mediatrix by any. O how sweetly brings Augustine in the Christian soule, when death is drawing neare it, speaking thus touching the onely Mediatour Iesus, and to the onely Mediatour Iesus:August. Tutius & incundius loquor ad meū Iesum, quam ad aliquem sanctorum spirituum Dei; plus debet mihi Christus quam alicui caelestium spirituum: Quod ego sum, fieri dignatus est Deus, non factus est quod est Angelus; ad curiam Dei sui, Dei tui, praecess • Deus tuus, homo tuus, tunica tua polymitica indutus: illic assidue pro nobis interpellat. Quem igitur habes intercessorem, habes Mediatorem, constituet ibi propitium adiutorem; & si Deus prote, quis contrate. I speake more surely, more ioyfully vnto my Iesus, then I can speake vnto any of the holy spirits of God: Christ is all and more vnto me then vnto any of those heauenly spirits. God dained himselfe to be that which I am: he was not made that which the Angels is. Thy God, thy man, clothed with thy particoloured coate hath gone before thee into the court and hall of this God, of thy God. There he doth alwayes intercede and make request for thee;
and therefore make him to be thy gracious helper, whom thou hast for thy Intercessour and Mediatour: and if God be with thee who can be against thee. When I consider this, ô my soule, I shall neuer wonder that Bernard knowing with Peter and Iohn, That among men there is giuen no name vnder the heauen whereby a man can be saued beside the name of Iesus, spake thus of the name of Iesus.Bernard. Nomen Iesus est mel in ore, melos in aure, iubilis in corde; nomen quod instar olei lucet praedicatum, pascit recogitatum, lenit & vngit inuocatum. The name of Iesus is honie in the mouth, pleasant melodie in the eare, aiubile and exultation in the heart. The name of Iesus is a name which being preached shines like oyle, being meditate vpon feedes, and which being called vpon comforts and annoints. O when shall the Papist be moued to see and confesse that to be true, which Augustine confesseth both truly & chearfully?Aug. ep. 49. Quanto magis pia est creatura, & subdita Deo, tanto minus se tali honore dignatur, quem scit non deberi nisi Deo: sancti Angeli non appetunt sacrificium, nisi quod ex doctrina vera sapientiae veraeque religionis offertur vns vero Deo, cui sancta societate deser • iunt. Pro
•• de sicut impia superbia, siue hominum siue
daemonum, sibi hos diuinos honores exhiberi, vel iubet, vel cupit; ita pia humilitas, vel hominum vel Angelorum sanctorum, haec sibi oblata recusauit, & cui deberetur ostendit. The more religious and subiect vnto God a creature is, it accounts it selfe to be lesse worthie of that honour which it knowes belongs to God. These holy Angels allowes no sacrifice, but that which according to the doctrine of true wisedome and religion is offered vp to that onely one true God. Therfore as the wicked pride, either of men or of Angels, commands or desires these honours to be giuen to them which be due to God; so the religious and holy humilitie either of men or of Angels, haue forsaken these things, and haue shewed men vnto whom they be due. And so holy Angels, holy men, true worshippers of the true God, do alwayes crie with that Angell which was sent to Iohn, Reuel. 22. • . Worship God.

THREE MOST FEAREFVLL ROCKES layed in the way of Gods babes, iourneying towards heauen: threatning their present ouerthrow, if they be not escheued by the light of the Spirit, their leader; and of the word their lanterne; holden forth by the man of God their watchman.

p.q: 2. TIM. 2. 19.The foundation of God remaineth sure, and hath this seale: The Lord knoweth who are his, and let euerie one that calleth vpon the name of the Lord depart frō iniquitie.
PSAL. 130. 4.Mercie or forgiuenesse is with thee that thou maiest be feared.
ROM. 6. 15.Shall we sinne because we are not vnder the Law but vnder grace? God forbid.
MAT. 7. 22.Not euerie one that saith vnto me Lord, shall enter into the kingdome of heauen, but he that doth the will of my father which is in heauen.
TIT. 1. 16.They professe that they know God, but by their workes they denie him, and are abominable, and disobedient, and to euerie good worke reprobate.

div.head: TO THE VERY SINCERELY RELIGIous, and truly Noble Lord; DAVID, Lord CARNEGY of Kinnard; Lord of his Maiesties priuie Counsell, and Senator of the honorable Colledge of Iustice.
div.p:
IF anie thing could come from my hands, my verie religious, Noble good Lord, worthie your Lordships fauorable countenance (vnlesse I would be accused by that twilight of nature, and condemned by that cleare light of grace, my God hath not altogether denied vnto me; blessed be his name) I am most strictly obliged, were I as swift of foote as
Hazael was, to runne with my whole strength to present it; both heartily, and humbly vnto your Lordship. Was I not so farre honoured of God being yet a babe? that from my infancie, I had your Lordships sincerely and truly religious father of most rare worthy memorie, for my louing, and kindest father? and since his Lordships death to this day, haue I not alwayes had your Lordship for my constant patrone, and louing fosterer? It hath pleased my good God to bring to my hands a subiect, not vnworthie your Lordships consideration; and which hath refused to go forth to the world vpon any condition, till it was couered vnder your Lordships nourishing, and protecting winges.

I haue reincountered with these cruell cunning Robbers, layed by Satan that Dragon and foxe in the way of the babes of God, to cut them off, lest they should in the end attaine
vnto that home of heauen they looke for: and discouered these Robbers to the sight of a valorous Dauid, who will proue readie, and able to apprehend and ouerthrow them.

I am now to meete (my worthy good Lord) with those fearefull Rockes, subtile Satan (abusing alas the foolish minds and foule hearts of manie professors) hath euen with their owne consent and applause, layed in their way to their wrack.

I am to come to that more then glorious Inne, towards the which the babes of God do iourney, and within the which they are to rest for euer. Yea, I am to intreate of the Guestes for whom that endlesse rest, which is to be found within the golden gates of this Inne, is prepared. Now to whom possibly could I haue presented these Rockes, to be considered and discouered vnto the babes of God, to the end that they might
eschue them beside your Lordship? who being taught of God, hath happily learned to adore Gods holy oracles, and to abhorre all hellish conclusions; and who is a Pilot ledde by the Spirit and lanterne of his word, is not onely able to shew the babes of God where these Rockes do lie, but by your Lorships wholesome counsell, and holy carriage, to stirre them vp to take their course by them.

Who so fit to allure men towards that Inne of heauen, as your Lordship? who liuing among men for some yeares, hath alwayes bene walking with God with Enoch, and before God with Abraham; hauing your conuersation in the heauens, setting your affections on things which are aboue, and not which are on the earth; and so able out of a sense of these things which God hath prepared for those who loue him, to exhort all men, casting away euerie
thing that presseth downe, Heb. 12. 12. and the sinne that hangeth so fast on, to runne with patience the race which is set before them, looking vnto Iesus, the author and finisher of their faith. To whom could I offer the consideration of the condition of these guests, for whom that Inne of heauen is prepared, omitting your Lordship? who being taught of God knowes, that not all those who crie:Mat. 7. 21. Lord, Lord, shall enter in the kingdome of heauen, but those who do the will of that father which is in heauen; 1. Ioh. 3. 2. 3 that whosoeuer hath this hope in him, that when Christ shall appeare he shall be like him, seeing him as he is; purgeth himselfe as he is pure. Alwaies (in respect of these large promises made vnto him by God) cleansing himselfe from all filthinesse of the flesh, 2. Cor. 71. 1 and spirit; and growing vp in full holinesse in the feare of God. From my soule, beseeching my good God for the sonne of his loues sake, so to sanctifie, and to guard your Lordships,
with your Lordships present, and future Noble posteritie that your Lordship with them, happily declining these fearefull Rockes, and pleasantly iourneying towards that heauenly Inne, may at length, as guests fitted of God for it, be receiued to lodge within it, possessing in Gods presence, fulnesse of ioy, and at his right hand, pleasures for euermore.

closer.signed: Your Lordships most humble deuoted: D. L.

div.head: THE FIRST ROCKE is a grosse abuse of Gods holy Predestination, and Election; which men of corrupt mindes, vnchast eares, blasphemous mouthes, and vile liues, peruert as they do other Scriptures, to their owne destruction.
div.p:
WOe is me, woe is me, ô my soule, that that bold vncleane spirit, should find (euen vnder this great and cleare light of the Gospell) not a few men, not onely mocke that comfortable doctrine of Gods eternall Predestination and Election; but tred it vnder foote, as the verie foundation of all securitie, and debaucherie; opening their foule mouthes, and spewing fotth like most vncleane dogges these vil • speeches: If I be appointed to heauen, let me wallow euen with pleasure in all kind of filthinesse, yet I shall be saued. Tremble, tremble, ô thou
blasphemer of the blessed word of the most high God, and repenting thy selfe of this thy wickednesse, pray God, that if it be possible, this hellish thought of thy diuellish heart and abhominable speech of thy vncleane lips, may be forgiuen thee: for beleeue me, the child of God appointed and looking for saluation, thought neuer thus, speakes neuer thus. Well is Gods child acquainted with the nature of Gods elect, and therefore he abhorres some, and loathes himselfe, onely for sinne; he smiles alwayes vpon holinesse, and loues himselfe onely in so farre as he finds himselfe endued with grace to loue and practise holinesse. True it is, ô my soule, that the elected child of God knowes that God his father did make choise of him in his Sonne Iesus before the foundation of the world. But with this he knowes that this was done not to the end that he should thinke, that he should speake, so loosely, so abhominably as the vile blasphemer of God, and the reprobate doth, but to the end, that he should be holy, and without blame before him in loue who did chuse him.Eph. 1. 4. Well is Gods elect child acquainted with
that great seale engrauen on both sides, and not on the one side alone, wherewith our God sealeth those he hath appointed to be heires of his euerlasting inheritance. Hauing on the one side this heauenly Motto: The foundation of God remaineth sure; and The Lord knoweth who is his owne. And here behold, ô my soule, beside this Motto, as it were ye pleasant pourtraicture of Gods free election drawne. And on the other side, hauing this for an inscription:2. Tim. 2. 19. Let euery one who calleth vpon the name of the Lord depart from iniquitie. And here behold, ô my soule, beside that inscription, y• shining pourtraicture of true sanctification, which Angels, which diuels, which men shall not be able to separate from Gods election. But which is more, ô my soule, the wise, humble, and holy elect child of God, well instructed out of the word of God his Fathers booke, out of the which he learnes all these lessons, whereby to gouerne himselfe: while he knowes that the election of God his Father stands euer most sure and stable, in respect of his God who changeth not; yet, feeling himselfe to be subiect to a verie world of tentations and crosses, he cannot
ceasse in the feare and reuerence of his God, whiles he liues here, to make his election more and more sure to h • mselfe, and that by eschewing all euill; the loue and practise whereof he knowes cannot stand with the election of God; and by louing and doing good, yea by ioyning goodnesse vnto goodnesse vncessantly: for he dare not attempt to thinke that his God hath drawne him toward his Maiestie by the soft and strong co • d of his eternall election, while Satan is pulling him backe, and he is willingly following after him, ledde in that blacke and vile halter of sinne. Thou must not wonder, ô my soule, that the elected child of God carrieth himselfe so, for are we not Gods children, thus charged by the Spirit? Giue diligence to make your calling and election sure, 1. Pet. 1. 5. 6 7. 8. ioyning vertue with your faith; and with vertue, knowledge; and with knowledge, temperance; and with temperance, patience; and with patience, godlinesse; and with godlinesse, brotherly kindnesse; and with brotherly kindnesse, loue: for if these things be amongst you, and abound, they will make you that ye neither shall be idle, nor vnfruitfull in the knowledge of our Lord Iesus Christ.

div.head: THE SECOND ROCKE is a foule abuse of the grace of God, which vncleane men turne into vncleane wantonnesse; delighting, alas, to commit sinne, because that good God delighteth to forgiue sinne.
div.p:
MAny wayes, alas, ô my soule, doth miserable man wrong God his gracious maker: yea, many men called Christians, do grosly grieue that holy one Iesus, who hath called them to that high dignitie to be called the sonnes of God: but in this specially, that they take occasion to commit sinne, yea to continue in sinne, with some pleasure and contentment, because God the Father out of his vndeserued loue, borne freely to man, hath giuen his Sonne to dye for man, because his blessed Sonne out of this same loue hath humbled himselfe willingly, yea, chearfully to the death for man; so that blind nature, common ciuilitie, Gods truth, their owne consciences, Angels, and well informed, or any waies, reformed men, cannot but condemne them, yea pronounce them to be execrable. Woe is me, ô my soule, that euer subtle and strong
Satan should haue preuailed so ouer man, that man now can be content to abuse that salue which is onely able to cure him, yea that he doth runne headlong vpon that sharpe slaying sword of sinne, because he heareth that salue is prepared for the curing of him. All men confesse, ô my soule, that that second couenant of grace made betwixt God and man in his blessed Sonne Iesus, that second Adam (who neuer fell nor can fall) is of greater moment, and alwayes more glorious then that first couenant of workes, which was made in that first Adam who stood not long, but fell fearefully. And canst thou deny but as our God hath obliged himselfe more strictly to man by this second couenant of grace, then he was by that first of works: so man is become nearer, yea sibber to God by the last then he was by the first; and in that respect obliged to worship and attend his Maiestie, so much the more diligently, faithfully, and constantly? findest thou, ô my soule, when thou readest and cōsiderest Scripture, but God thy maker, perceiuing that first couenant of workes made betwixt him and man, broken by man, prooued iust; and so adiudged man
with all his posteritie vnto that death threatned against him and them, in case that couenant should be violated by them? And shall not our God, hauing giuen his owne Sonne for man, proue much more iust in condemning all such who dare attempt to despise that bloud shed by him for sinne, by selling themselues ouer to sinne, because his bloud was shed for buying them from sinne? If a Iew hauing the Law of God put in his hand by Moses, Leuit. 18. 5. hearing Moses sound this in his eares:Deut. 27. 26. Do this and liue: Cursed be he that confirmeth not all the words of this Law to do them: could with Abraham see by faith the day of the blessed Messias a farre off, and reioyce in it, he were easily freed from that curse: for blessed Iesus (who was made a curse for vs) blesseth all those whom Moses curseth, prouiding they can repent and beleeue in him. But ô Gentile, liuing now not vnder the Law, but vnder the Gospell, not hauing Moses, the seruant of God for thy doctor, but Iesus, the Son of God for thy Maister: what if thou shalt take vpon thee not to abuse that Law giuen by Moses, but that grace dearely cost and louingly brought to thee by Iesus?
