where shalt thou finde salue to cure thy sore, and medicine to heale thy disease? Let me anger Moses through breaking of the Law: let Moses threaten me for breaking of the Law: If I can but touch with a liuely faith the hemme of Iesus garment, I shall find peace with God, and health with life to my selfe. But if I shall anger Iesus, who shall pacifie him? where shall I find a sacrificer, to satisfie him; hauing despised that bloud shed by him for me? Oh, ô my soule, when shall that sentence, yea, that byting sentence be hearkened vnto, by the monstrous, vile, loose gospellers of this profane, licentious, leacherous time, He that despised Moses, died without mercie, vnder two or three witnesses. Of how much sorer punishments suppose ye, shall he be worthy which treadeth vnder foote the Sonne of God, and counteth the bloud of the Testament as an vnholy thing, wherewith he was sanctified, and doth despise the Spirit of grace. That patient who among men doth despise the kindest wisest,Heb. 10. 28. 29. the painefullest, and best approued Physician, is thought to be desperately diseased? And shall not that man, ô my soule, who dare (taking
himselfe to sinne, Christs onely enemie) neglect Iesus, renounce Iesus medicine, die for euermore? for can Angels, can Saints, triumphing in heauen, can Saints fighting on earth, yea, can diuels euer dying in hell cure him, whō Iesus will not cure, who dare refuse to be cured by Iesus? Yea, who is not affrayed to cast that cup (euen the blessed word of God, and Sacraments annexed thereto, in the which the wholesome potions of saluation are kept, and by the which they are conueyed to the sicke soules of Gods children) vnder his feete? Do not Peter and Iohn triumphantly crie.Act. 4. 12. There is no name vnder the heauen by the which a man can be saued, but by the name of Iesus. Yea, doth not Augustine, August. who was no Papist, taught of God and ledde by Scripture, maintaine that which Peter and Iohn did proclaime: for he doth see no Sauiour, but one; euen sweet Iesus: Nemo liberat à vulneribus illius trucidatores, nisi gratia saluatoris; nemo liberat venundatos sub peccato, à vinculis captiuitatis, nisi gratia redimentis. None freeeth man from the wounds of that murtherer, but the grace of that Sauiour: none deliuereth those who be sold vnder sinne, from the bonds
of spirituall captiuitie and thraldome, but his grace who redeemeth them. Sure I am, ô my soule, were Iude, that blessed Apostle of Iesus, liuing this day, he would change his tune, if he were writing either to vs, or of vs, (who liues now vnder such a dispised, abused, great light) writing to those of his time,Iude 4. he was content to say: There are certaine men crept in, which were before of old ordained to this condemnation; vngodly men there are which turne the grace of our God into wantonnesse, and denie God the onely Lord, and our Lord Iesus Christ. But were Iude liuing now among vs, he could not but say, and write thus: There be manie men, who do resort to the house of God, who call vpon the name of God, who daily in troopes runne on foote, ride on horsebacke, keeping their solemne meetings in citie and countrey, who turne the sauing grace of God into damnable wantonnesse, denying (albeit not with their foule mouthes, yet by their vile deeds) that God and Lord who would haue saued them. Oh, ô my soule, when shall that golden sentence written by Augustine be heard of vs,August. who liues now? be honoured and embraced by vs as a wholesome medicine able to cure vs? as a
precious Iewell able to honour vs? Quid nobis gratia Dei vtilius confert in hoc praesenti seculo maligno, Aug. Epist. 47. nisi vt moriamur peccato? ac per hoc ipsi gratiae inuenietur ingratus, qui propter illam vult viuere peccato, per quam morimur peccato. Iude 4. What more profitable thing doth the grace of God in this present wicked world bring to vs, then that by it we are made to do the same? so that, that man must by this be found vnthankefull to the grace of God, who because of it, will liue in sinne, by the which we are made able to die to sinne? Oh when shall the loose gospellers hearken to Irenaeus saying to them? Vt aucta est gratia sub nouo Testamento, ita & poena eorum qui non credunt. As grace is augmented now vnder the Gospell, so the punishmēt of those, who beleeue not, is encreased also. And no wonder that he write so, considering that his Maister writ before him touching Chorasin, Bethsaida, and Capernaum: Wo be to thee Chorasin, wo be to thee Bethsaida, for if the great workes, which were done in you, had bene done in Tirus, and Sidon, they had repented long ago in sackcloath and ashes. Mat. 11. 21. 23. 24. Therefore I say vnto you, it shall be easier for Tirus, and Sidon, at the day of Iudgement then for you. And thou
Capernaum which are lifted vp vnto the heauen, shall be brought downe to hell, for if the great workes which haue bene done in thee, had bene done among them in Sodome, they had remained to this day. But I say vnto you it shall be easier for them of the land of Sodom at the day at Iudgement then for thee. Giue no place to sinne, ô my soule, because Christ died for sinne, and by his death hath purchased remission of sins to thee, not forgetting thee: which the Apostle saith to thee.2. Cor. 15. 14. 17. If one be dead for all, then were all dead: and be died for all, that they which liue should not hence forth liue vnto themselues, but vnto him which died for them, and rose againe. Therefore if any man be in Christ let him be a new creature.

div.head: THE THIRD ROCRE IS A foolish leaning (without anie ground) to a naked profession of God, with the mouth, without any practise of godlinesse in thy life.
div.p:
COmparing the protestation of our professors, with their conuersation, I haue for some bygone yeares lamented
(before my God in secret,) ô my soule, the desperate estate of this our deaddest age. Our professors do protest that they do know and worship that God who made not only the heauens and the earth, but who made that booke which is onely worthy the stile of a booke, to wit, the Bible, and that they hold this booke, for the booke of this God; indited by his Spirit, and put in register by his pen-men, ledde by this same spirit: yet our professors so liue, as all who do looke on them, and heare them (being truly sensible of the true God, and truly instructed by the Spirit of truth out of his word) must euen solemnely sweare, that the effects of a great manie of them, do either denie this God who made the Bible, to be that God whom they worship; or the Bible to be Gods booke. Offend not rashly, ô my soule, that I speake so to thee: for after triall (alas) this will proue to be most true. If our professors did hold that God who made that booke which we call the Bible for their God, would they not striue to worship him, and to liue with men, and among men, as God by this his booke hath appointed them to
do? Againe, if our professors, ô my soule, held the Bible for Gods booke, indited by his Spirit who cannot lye, calling nothing good but that which is good before God, and which leadeth man toward the narrow way of saluation, calling nothing euill but that which is euill before God, and which draweth man towards the broad way of perdition, could they be so easily induced to transgresse those lessons our God by this booke teacheth them, and vnder no lesse paine then of remedilesse, endlesse, condemnation commands them to obey? yea, durst they for ten thousand worlds attempt to do this? I wonder, ô my soule, if our gallants (whom nothing can tame) do hold that speech for the speech of God (who cannot lye of faine)?Eccles. 11. 9 Reioyce ô yong man in thy youth, and let thy heart cheare thee in the dayes of thy youth, and walke in the wayes of thine heart, and in the sight of thine eyes, but know that for all these things God will bring thee to iudgement. Eccl. 12. 14. God will bring euery worke vnto iudgement with euery secret thing whether it be good or euill. I wonder if our mad whoremaisters and whoores, if our abhominable blasphemers, if our brutish drunkards,
if our filthie speakers, do hold these speeches for the speeches of the great God, before whom they must one day appeare, and giue an account of their whole carriage here, publicke in the streets and priuate in chamber, by night and by day? Men do not despise a thiefe when he stealeth to satisfie his soule, Prou. 6. 30. 31. 32. 33. 34. 35. because he is hungrie; but if he be found he shall restore to seuen fold, or he shall giue all his substance of his house: but he that committeth adulterie with a woman is destitute of vnderstanding he that doth it, destroyeth his owne soule, he shall find a wound and dishonour, and his reproach shall neuer be taken away. For iealousie is as the rage of man, therefore he will not spare in the day of vengeance, he cannot heare the sight of anie ransome, neither will be consent though thou augment the price. 1. Cor. 6. 9. 10. Know ye not that the vnrighteous shall not inherit the kingdome of God? Be not deceiued, neither fornicators, nor idolaters, Ephes. 5. 3. 4. 5. 6. nor adulterers, nor wantons, nor buggerers, nor theeues, nor couetous, nor drunkards, nor raylers, nor extortioners, shall inherit the kingdome of God. But fornication and all vncleanenesse, or couetousnesse, let it not be once named among you, as it becometh Saints; neither filthinesse, neither foolish talking,
neither iesting, which are things not comely, but rather giuing of thankes. For this ye know, that no whooremonger, neither vncleane person, nor couetous person, which is an idolater, hath any inheritance in the kingdome of Christ and of God. Let no man deceiue you with vaine words; for, for such things commeth the wrath of God vpon the children of disobedience: be not therefore companions with them. Reu. 21. 8. But the fearefull and vnbeleeuing, and the abhominable, and murtherers, and whooremongers, and sorcerers, and idolaters, and all lyers, shall haue their part in the lake, which burneth with fire and brimstone, which is the second death. Yea, I wonder, ô my soule, if the Kings and Princes, and mightie men of this world do hold that speech for the speech of God: And the kings of the earth, and the great men, and the rich men, Reu. 6. 15. 16. 17. and the chiefe captaines, the mightie men, and euery bondman, and euery free man hid themselues in dennes, and among the rockes of the mountaines, and said to the mountaines and rockes fall on vs, and hide vs from the presence of him that sitteth vpon the throne, and from the wrath of the Lambe; for the great day of his wrath is come, and who can stand? Our professors then, ô my
soule, for the most part can neither hold that God who made the Bible for their God, neither the Bible for his booke, considering that sensible, hard, and seene exposition, may easily be found to be betwixt their liues and Gods lessons taught in this Bible. And therefore without doubt, they haue madly (miscarried by that vncleane spirit) set vp to themselues their owne hearts lustes, to be both their God, whom they will serue, and that onely booke which they will learne and follow. I know one Scripture, ô my soule, which shall condemne thousands, who heare and reade Scripture (alledging they hold it for Gods word) vnlesse they repent speedily.Iam. 2. 12. Thou beleeuest that there is a God, thou doest well. The diuels also beleeue and trembleth. Oh, ô my soule, when shall a great many amongst vs, and professing with vs, learne to do that which the diuell doth; well knowes he, that the onely true God who made the heauen, and the earth, made the Bible also; and that this Bible is the booke of that God, who is the onely true God, yea, that all things contained in it be most true: albeit, alas, many men neglect and contemne
that which they heare out of the Bible, that which they reade in the Bible, while the diuel knowing these things can tremble, assured that he is adiudged by that most great and most iust Iudge of the world vnto eternall condemnation, as the Bible speaketh. Shall Satan who doth beleeue Gods word to be true, and who can tremble at the sound of it be condemned? and shall he escape the feare • ullest damnation which shall be found in hell, who is so far from trembling at the iudgements of God, brought to his eares out of Gods word, that he makes but a mocke of them? It were good they were thinking vpon that, spoken by our God touching the old foolish vncleane Iewes: Will ye steale, Ier. 7. 9. 10. and murther, and commit adulterie, and sweare falsly, and burne incense vnto Baal, and walke after other gods whom ye know not, and come and stand before me in this house whereupon my name is called, and say we are deliuered, though we haue done all these abhominations? Were Paul liuing, sure I am, no sooner would he lend his eares vnto a great many of our professours, but he would say ouer againe: They professe that they know God, Tit. 1. 16. but by their workes they
denie him, and are abhominable and disobedient, and to euery good worke reprobate. And no wonder, for the voice of our blind sensuall professours is this, ô my soule: I loue God, and cursed be he who loues not God. But, ô blind foole, when shalt thou begin from an heart sensible of God, and with a cleane mouth honouring God, to say, I loue godlinesse, and cursed shall he proue at length who loues not godlinesse. The voice of our blind sensuall professors is this, I hate the diuell, I defie the diuell, and all his works. But when shall they begin from an honest heart, and with true lips to say, I hate sin, and cursed shall he proue at length who hates not sinne. O when shall that of Augustine be taken to heart by our vncleane professours?Ep. 171. Christianos vos dicitis & Christo contradicitis. Ye call your selues Christians, and you contradict Christ alwayes. Open our professours eyes ô Lord by thy Spirit, to the end that they may once happily see that which Bernard brought to the eares of the loose professours of his time: Vnde tibi gloria putide puluis? de vitae sanctitate, quid tibi prodest pium Saluatoris nomen lectitare in libris: nec habere pietatem in moribus. Whence commeth glorie and honour
vnto thee, ô stinking dust, from the holinesse of thy life I thinke it commeth onely? for what can it profit thee to reade the holy name of thy Sauiour in bookes, while that thou hast not holinesse in thy manners. And againe. Is Scripturas recte legit, qui verba vertit in opera. That man readeth holy Scripture aright, who turneth words into workes; doth that in his life which he reades in the Scripture.

THAT ONELY GLORIOVS INNE, AND BRIGHTLY SHIning palace, filled with all pleasures and ioyes, towards the which the Babes of God do iourney in time laboriously: and in the which they shall liue eternally, with the nature and condition of those babes who shall possesse it.
div.q: In my Fathers house are many dwelling places, if it were not so, I would haue told you: I go to prepare a place for you.
Father, I will that these whom thou hast giuen me be with me where I am; that they may behold the glorie which thou hast giuen me, for thou louest me before the foundation of the world.

Blessed and holy is he, who hath part in the first resurrection, for on such the second death hath no power: but they shall be the Priests of God, and of Christ, and shall reigne with him a thousand yeare.

div.head: THE INNE WITHIN THE WHICH THE BABES of God carried in this heauenly Chariot, lookes to lodge and alwayes to rest; is that new Ierusalem which is aboue, where there is fulnesse of ioy to be found in Gods presence, and pleasures lasting for euermore at his right hand.
div.p:
THat Inne towards the which this heauenly golden Chariot drawne by these heauenly white horfes, carries these babes of God, (happily ledde and directed by the Spirit, and enlightned by the lanterne of the word, held in the hand of the Preachers thereof) free of the foresaid Robbers, and Rockes; is that new Ierusalem which is aboue, made vp of pure gold, like cleare glasse; whose wall, ô my soule, is of lasper, founded vpon twelue precious
stones: euen vpon a Iasper, a Saphire, a Chalcedome, an Emeraud, a Sardonix, a Sardin, a Chrysolite, a Berill, a Topaz, a Chrysophrasus, a Iacinth, a Amathist: whose twelue gates, are twelue pearles also, whose streetes are pure gold shining like glasse, whose temple the Lord God almightie and the Lambe is, which hath neither Sunne, nor Moone, beside the glorie of God, and of the Lambe. In the light whereof the people that are saued do walke, and to the which the kings of the earth shall bring their glorie, and honour; whose gates are neuer shut, which is inriched with a pure riuer of water of life, cleare as cristall, springing out of the Throne of God, and of the Lambe; hauing in the midst of the streete of it, and on the other side of the riuer that tree of life which beareth twelue manner of fruites, and giueth fruite euerie moneth, the leaues whereof do heale the nations, where Gods seruants being free from all curse, (for no curse can possibly enter there) shall serue him, seeing alwayes his face, and hauing his name written in their foreheads, reigning with him for euer. But canst thou tell me, ô my soule, what
shall be the estate and condition of those who shall be admitted to be citizens within this new Ierusalem, and Inne of heauen, they being once happily possessed of it? To handle this matter to the full, and so to lay open to thee, ô my soule, the nature of this Inne as it deserueth, and as it is in it selfe; it is not in the power of Angels, or of men: for heare I note first that royall,Esay 64. 4. Euangelicke, Prophet Isaiah, and then that great Apostle Paul crying out:1. Cor. 2. 9. The eye hath not seene, the eare hath not heard, neither came it to mans heart, to thinke of these things which God prepareth for them that loue him? 2. Cor. 12. 4 Yea, Paul who had a greater proofe of the beautie, glory, aand superabundant riches of the things which are to be found in this Inne, being rauished vp towards it, confesseth that he saw things there not to be vttered. Hearken, hearken therefore, ô my soule, I pray thee, for heare I must tell thee that the skilfulnesse of Arithmeticke can not number out these good things which are to be found there. That the deepenesse of Geometrie, cannot measure the length, and breadth, the higth, and the depth of those good things which be layed vp
there: Yea, that the swiftest and sweetest tongue of the most rarely eloquent Orator, is not sufficient to expresse the worthie, and excellencie of them: for when this Citie, and Inne is looked vpon by him whose eyes be enlightened from aboue by the Lord of it. The Arithmetician, the Geomerticiā the Orator must stand amazed and crie out. Neuer saw I an Inne before, ye pleasures, the plenishing, the beautie whereof I was not able to reckon, to measure, and to declare. But behold here an Inne, filling my eares so, my eyes so, my smelling so, my tasting so, my touching so, yea, my heart aboue all things so; that I am like (through the superabundance of passing excellent things, may delight my hearing my seeing, my tasting, my touching, and if I were not sustained by a stronger, euen by that blessed, yea, onely Lord and Ma • ster of this Inne) to loose my hearing by hearing, my sight by beholding, my smelling by smelling, my tasting by tasting, my touching by touching; those things which be there to be heard, seene, smelled, tasted, and touched. Yea, I would loose my verie heart and life. And no wonder, ô my soule, yt it be so, for
in that Inne of heauen, thy God shall be a bright shining looking glasse to thy sight, a sweetly sounding Fluit, & Cimball to thy hearing, a delicious honie combe to thy tast, odoriferous balme to thy smelling, and a passing wonderfull soft pleasant rose to thy touching: What man of sharpest sight can behold this outward Sunne which God himselfe hath appointed to enlighten this world, which is the common Inne of the elect, and reprobate, in his full brightnesse and glorie, and not haue his eyes hurt thereby? And shalt thou, ô my soule, behold that supreamest Maiestie of the Father, and of the Lambe, that onely Sonne which doth enlighten this Inne, (within the which no reprobate can enter) vnlesse thou be fortified by one stronger then thy selfe, and blessed with a more strong, quicke sight then thou canst here beneath attaine vnto? what mans eares are not transported, when he heares a number of sweete voyces, singing artificiall musicke in diuerse parts formerly and melodiously. And shalt thou not find thy selfe wonderfully transported, ô my soule, when thou shalt be brought within thy Inne, to be a hearer, not onely
of the sweetest musicke of the glorified Saints; but of these celestiall Spirits the Angels, there inioying the pleasures of the spring, the glorie of the Summer, the plentie of the haruest, and the sweet rest of the Winter? But no wayes hearing, or seeing, or feeling any hurt which euer came to man by any of these. This moued Bernard meditating vpon the estate of Gods glorified children in heauen,Ber. Ser. 33. in cant. to burst forth in these words, not without a speciall exclamation, and admiration: O perenne Solstitium, quando iam non inclinabitur dies! ô lumen meridianum! ô vernalis temperies! ô aestiua venustas! ô autumnalis vbertas! ô quies & feriatio hiemalis! O euerduring stay of the Sunne, (for that Sunne which shineth in this Inne, neuer goeth downe, but alwayes shineth in his hight) when the day shall not incline to the end! (for the day which riseth in this Inne shall last for euer) O noone-tide light! ô the sweetest temperance of the spring! ô the pleasantnesse of the Summer! ô the plentie and abundance of the haruest! ô the rest and refreshing vacants of the Winter! If this low house of the world, be so richly furnished with a verie world of diuerse pleasant, profitable, and
glorious things, (being the lodging not onely of the children of God, but of the children of wrath) ô how rich must that house of God be furnished with pleasure, profit, and glorie; within the which none can dwell, beside that blessed great Gods elect Angels, and dearest sonnes, and daughters! Augustine finding himselfe ouercome by the consideration of the glorie of this Inne of heauen, could say: Si id quod ex parte est non valuit eloqui ne • expertus, quid de perfectione inexpertus balbutire conatur. Oculus non viditò Deus absque te, quae praeparasti diligentibus; pax super pacem, indeficiens exultatio, torrens voluptatis diuinae, flumen laetitiae, gaudium plenum; cogita quicquid vis, quicquid potes exopta, excedit cogitationem omnem, desiderium omne exuperat illa felicitas, aeternitas illa, beatitudo illa. If that which is but in a part could not be expressed by him who had proofe thereof, wherefore should he who is inexpert, attempt to babble about it. The eye sees not ô God without thee the things which thou hast prepared for those that loue thee: peace aboue peace, triumphant indeficient ioy, a peale of heauenly pleasure, a floud of gladnesse, full ioy: thinke vpon any thing thou pleasest, wish
after what thou may; that happinesse, that eternitie, that blessednesse, surmounteth all a man can thinke, and sensibly ouercomes all a man can desire. Augustine pressing to make this his assertion cleere vnto vs, can crie out.Aug. de doc. Chrsti. lib. 1. cap. 15. Quibus verbis dici, aut qua cogitatione capi potest, praemiū quod Christus in vita futura daturus est? quando ad consolationem huius itineris tantum dedit de suo spiritu, vt quod faciendum est, non solum sine murmure sed etiam cum dilectione, & delectatione faceamus, in aduersis etiam gaudentes, & fiduciam in eum, quem non videmus, ponentes: By what words can that reward be expressed, or by what thought can that reward be apprehended, which Christ shall giue to his owne in the life to come? seeing for the consolation, and sweetning of this their iourney, he hath giuen them such a measure of his owne Spirit, that we are made to do that which we should do, not onely without murmuring, but also out of loue, and with pleasure, reioycing euen in tribulations, and putting our confidence in him, whom as yet we see not. O what happinesse, what honour, what glorie, what peace, what charitie? yea, what incomparable plentie of all things, shall the glorified Saints inioy there? Shall not that
happinesse be wonderfull excellent there, where no euill can be found, where no good thing can be wanting? What a glorie shall be there, where none who is praised can be praised, either by the error, or the flatterie of those who do praise them? What honour shall be there, when honors shall not be refused to any who is worthy of honour, neither can be giuen to anie who is vnworthie; yea, where none vnworthie of honour shall presse for honour, and where none can come but those who be worthie of it? what peace shall be there, where none can possibly suffer any hurt or wrong, either from themselues or from any other? O what loue shall be there, where no inferiour shall enuie the superiour, nor any superiour contemne the inferiour! O how excellent shall the free-will of man be there, ô my soule! When God made Adam to his owne Image, he beautified him with that free-will, whereby he might haue not sinned. But in that Inne of heauen this shall be mans happie freewill, and mans happinesse, because of this his free-will that he shall not be able to sinne. O what plentie shall be there possessed by man, when he shall haue nothing
which he would want, and when he shall want nothing which he would haue? Augustine saw this when he said: In ciuitate superna, Aug ep. 3. atque diuina, iam non est molestè toleranda calamitas, nec laboriosè fraenanda cupiditas, sed sola sine vlla difficultate, & perfecta libertate retinenda, Dei & proximi, charitas. In that heauenly Citie which is aboue, there shall be no calamitie with trouble to be suffered, neither any concupiscence or lust with paine to be bridled: but there the onely loue of our God and of our neighbour to be retained and kept without any difficultie and paine, and with perfect libertie and freedome. The sense hereof moued Bernard to say:Bern. In coelis erit securitas libera, & libertas secura, neque aduertendi erunt de caetero oculi ne videant vanitatem; quia purissimam videbunt venustatem, quae est ista copia, vbi nihil quod nolis sit, vbi totum sit quod velis. In the heauens there shall be free securitie, and secure freedome, for there the children of God shall not haue occasion any more to aduert to their eyes, that they behold not vanitie, because they shall alwayes see most pure and pleasant comelinesse: ô what abundance is this, where there is nothing which thou wouldst not haue, and where all
that is which thou wouldst haue. And thus thou mayst see, ô my soule, that the glorie and happinesse of this Inne of heauen consisteth in two things: to wit, in the absolute necessarie presence of all good, and in the absolute necessarie want of all euill things: for in it there is such abundant beautie of euerlasting righteousnesse, such an inexpressible pleasant world of shining, quickening, and refreshing light, that howbeit it were not lawful for a man to stay there, but for the space of a short day; yet for a very short dayes abiding there, he would heartily content himselfe to despise and depriue himselfe of all the pleasures, honour, and wealth can be found here, and with ioy vndergo and vnderlye all those euils he can suffer here, to the end he might but liue there but for the space of a short day. Had Dauid (out of the sense of these comforts which were to be found by the exercise of religion) the outward tabernacle of God in such account,Psal. 84. 1 •
yt he could say: A day in thy courts is better then a thousand other where: I had rather be a doore keeper in the house of my God, then to dwell in the tabernacles of wickednesse. And shalt thou not find in the end
of thy time, when thou shalt enter within that Inne of glorie, that it were better to stay there for one day if it were possible, then to liue with Methusalah 969. yeares, adorned with vncertaine, perishing pleasures▪ honours, and riches? Beside this, ô my soule, knewest thou what a stole thou shalt weare in this Inne of heauen? yea, with what a stole this my bodie shall be clothed there, ô with what earnestnesse wouldst thou call for the comming of Iesus! ô with what earnest desire wouldst thou long for the comming of Iesus! yea, ô what praises wouldst thou sing to God thy Father, who hath promised this Inne to thee, to God thy Sauiour, who hath conquised this Inne to thee, and to God the holy Ghost, who assures thee that this Inne belongs to thee! Thou, ô my soule, in that Inne of heauen, shalt be richly and royally decked with a threefold stole; in beautie, in worth, farre surpassing all those ornaments and iewels, rich Salomon was couered with, when he sat in his royall throne: with the stole of the perfect knowledge of the blessed and glorious Trinitie; Father, Sonne, and holy Ghost; and this perfect knowledge shall fill vp
the roome of that liuely iustifying faith wherewith on earth here thou art blessed, and by the which thou apprehendest the promises of God made to thee in thy Sauiour: for when thou shalt enter, ô my soule, within the doores of this Inne of heauen (all being giuen thee which was promised to thee, and beleeued by thee) thy faith shall ceasse, and this perfect knowledge of God shall meete thee, and keepe thee for euer. Secondly, thou shalt be clothed with the stole of the perfect fruition of inioying of the glorious Trinitie; the Father, Sonne, and holy Ghost. And this fruition shall fill vp the roome of that Hope which now thou hast; for so soone as thou shalt come to the gates of this heauenly Inne, in that day of iudgement that Hope, whereby thou expectest now those things, thy Father hath promised, thy Sauiour hath conquised, and the Spirit assures thee of, shall ceasse also. And this fruition shall fill the roome of it, thou being fully possessed with all thou expected. Thirdly, with the stole of the perfect loue of the blessed Trinitie, the Father, Sonne, and holy Ghost; and of the Saints his children, for then that loue
wherewith thou, ô my soule, now louest thy Father, thy Sauiour, thy Sanctifier, and his children shall not then end with thy faith and hope, when thou shalt enter within the gates of this Inne; but shall go in with thee, and being there augmented, and perfected by a thousand thousand degrees, shall possesse thee for euermore. This moued that Apostle who was well acquainted with these things which be in heauen to say:1. Cor. 13. 13. Now abideth faith, hope, and loue, euen these three; but the chiefest of these is loue. And therefore Irenaeus taught by the Spirit, and by Paul, subscribing hereunto could write thus: Charitas pretiosior est cognitione, gloriosior prophetia, & omnibus charismatibus supereminet. Loue is more pretious then knowledge, more gracious then prophecie, yea, it surmounts all gifts man hath. This my bodie againe in that heauenly Inne, ô my soule, shall be clothed and adorned with a fourefold stole: first, with the stole of rare beautie and holinesse, so that the Sunne in his full brightnesse did neuer shine so gloriously as my bodie shall shine in that Inne. Tels not Daniel me that in the Inne of heauen: The wise shall shine as the brightnesse of the firmament, Dan. 12. 3.
and they that turne many to righteousnesse as the starres for euer and euer. Yea, are not these the words of thy Sauiour who cannot lye:Mat 8. 43. Then shall the iust men shine as the Sunne in the kingdome of their Father. Now thou must not wonder, ô my soule, that euen the blackest & palest coloured bodie of the glorified child of God shall thus shine: for art thou not thus resolued by the Spirit? We looke from the heauens for the Sauiour euen the Lord Iesus Christ, Phil. 3 20. 21. who shall change our vile bodies that it may be fashioned like vnto his glorious bodie. Now if Christ giuing his disciples Peter, Iames, and Iohn, before Moses and Elias, a little view of that glorie which is due to him, had his face shining as the Sunne, and his clothes white as the light, while he was onely transfigurate vpon mount Tabur? ô with what a glorie is he now clothed, in that mountaine of glorie with his Father! and and how shall our bodies shine,1. Ioh. 3. 2. who in heauen shall be like him,1. Cor. 5. 49. bearing there the image of that heauenly Adam, as here we beare the image of the earthly? Secondly, with that singular stole of impossibilitie, so that howbeit the bodies of the Saints of God be subiect to a thousand alterations,
and hazards which do manie wayes trouble and annoy them, yet then they shall be free of all suspition of alteration,Reuel. 21. 4. or hazard, all these first things which here do trouble men being ended. Thirdly, with that excellent stole of wonderfull Agilitie, for then our lumpish bodies shall be freed of that heauinesse which now doth clogge them, and make vs, that without great difficultie and paine, we cannot go from place to place: yea, that without some outward helpe we cannot vpon a sudden transport our selues, where we would fainest be. For now the spirit cannot go but where the bodie goeth (the bodie being a burthen to it) but then the spirit being made the full maister of the bodie, shall command it to go without any trouble wheresoeuer it would haue it to go. And therefore Augustine could say: Tanta erit tunc corporis agilitas, vt vbi volet spiritus ibi protinus erit & corpus. Then the child of God being in heauen, the agilitie and nimblenesse of the bodie shall be so great, that where euer the spirit would be, there the bodie shall be also incontinent. Now thou must no wayes doubt of this, ô my soule, considering as thou hast heard that our bodies
in heauen shall be conforme to the bodie of our blessed Sauiour, and so as Christs bodie after his resurrection was adorned with such agilitie, that in a most short space it could be seene in diuerse places, now at Ierusalem, now out of Ierusalem, comming to his disciples vnawares, & vpon a suddaine departing from them,Ioh. 20. 19. 26. as Iohn witnesseth: our glorified bodies shall euen in this be like vnto his. Yea, what shall I say, shall the bodie of the Prophet Elias, Luk. 24. 31. and of Philip the Deacon, soiourning beneath here, be transported vpon a suddaine from place to place by the Lord our God:1 King. 18. 12. 46. and shall we doubt that our bodies being glorified, and made like to the bodie of Christ shall be inferiour to them in this point?Acts 8. 9. And ô how farre shall this augment the ioy of the glorified Saints, while we liue here: ô how often do we desire to be with those who be dearest to vs, and of whom we are specially loued? yea, is it not a matter of speciall griefe euen to the dearest Saints of God, that knowing themselues to haue deere brethren and sisters, some in that same kingdome with them, others in diuerse kingdomes farre remoued from
them, lying vnder sharpe crosses and diuerse afflictions whom they are not able, notwithstanding of this, to visite, for imparting the sweet honie of consolation to them, being hindered through distance of place from them. But in heauen, ô how soone shall we find our selues, not onely in minde but in bodie also present with such we do loue, and who do loue vs. Then Dauid shall haue no cause to crie from a wounded heart, and with a mourning tune and countenance:Psal. 42. 1. 2 As the Hart brayeth for the riuers of water, so panteth my soule for thee ô God. My soule thirsteth for God, euen for the liuing God, when shall I come and appeare before the presence of God? my teares haue bene my meate day and night, while they say daily where is thy God? There Paul shall haue no neede to crie out:Rom. 7. 14. 24. What I would that do I not, but what I hate that do I. O wretched man that I am who shall deliuer me from the bodie of this death? If the expectation of these wayes, ô my soule,Iob. 19. 25. 26. 27. which be in heauen, made Iob (inuironed with an inward and outward sea of tentations and crosses) not onely to digest them, but digesting them to reioyce in the midst of them: ô what ioy
shall the full fruition of them procure him? Fourthly, in this Inne of heauen thou shalt be cloathed, ô my soule, with the stole of perfect health, and strength; so that where now the bodie of Gods child is not onely subiect to great weakenesse, but to innumerable grieuous, and most painfull diseases, there it shall be fully, and finally deliuered from all▪ weaknesse, or from all feare of any paine or disease whatsoeuer. This is that whereof the Spirit would assure thee, when he saith:Reuel. 21. 4. 5. 6. Behold the tabernacle of God is with men, and he will dwell with them: and they shall be his people, and God himselfe shall be their God with them, and God shall wipe away all teares from their eyes, and there shall be no more death, neither sorrow, neither crying, neither shall there be any more paine, for the first things are passed, and he that sate vpon the throne said: Behold I make all things new, and he said vnto me, write, for these words are faithfull and true. Yea, in this Inne of heauen, one shall be knowne by euerie one, euerie one by all, embracing one another, as now the members of one bodie embrace one another; so that thou ô my soule, shalt then loue all the children
of God as thou shalt loue thy selfe, and shalt be loued by him, as thou shalt loue them: for whosoeuer shall be there, and all those who shall be there, shall be one bodie, shall be one Church, shall be one spouse to blessed Iesus; and therefore the will of one shall be the will of all: yea, which is more, ô my soule, there the will of God shall not differ from thy will, nor thy will from Gods will; albeit (alas) while thou shalt soiourne beneath here, there shall alwayes remaine most grosse, and fearefull contrarieties, betwixt the good will of thy good God, and thy peruerse euill will. Did Adam in his innocencie know Euah whom he had neuer seene before, and giue her a fit name so soone as she was presented before him? and shalt thou being aduanced to a higher dignitie in a farre more excellent pallace, not know all who shall be there? Shall Peter when our Maister was transfigurate vpon mount Tabur, know Moses, and Elias, whom he had neuer seene before? and shall I not know them when I shall be glorified by him, and with them in the mountaine of glorie? I will not denie, ô my soule, but in this Inne of heauen; there
shall be degrees of glorie, 1. Cor. 15. 40. 41. euen as there is another glorie of the Sunne, and another glorie of the Moone, and another glorie of the starres, for one starre differeth from another in glorie. This is that the Spirit would cleere vnto vs,Dan. 12. 3. when he saith: They that be wise shall shine as the brightnesse of the firmament, and they that turne manie to righteousnesse shall shine as the starres for euermore. And we know that there is difference betwixt the brightnesse of the firmament, and the brightnesse of the starres. But I must tell thee, ô my soule, that this is the priuiledge of this Inne of heauen, that none inioying greatest glorie is enuied by him who inioyes lesse, that none possessing lesse glorie is condemned by him who inioyes lesse, that none possessing lesse glorie is condemned by him who possesseth more; and therefore out of this sense I heare Augustine saying:August. Quòd ibi futuri sint gradus hominum, nullatenus ambigendum est, verum beata illa ciuitas magnum in se bonum videbit; quod nulli superiori nullus inferior videbitur, tam nollet vnusquisqueesse quod non accepit. Sic itaque habebit donum alius alio minus vt hoc quoque donum habeat quod non volet amplius. That in heauē
there shall be degrees of men we must no wayes doubt. That blessed Citie shall see that great good in her, that no inferior shall appeare inferior to any superiour; so farre shall euerie one not desire to be that which he hath not receiued & so one shall haue a gift lesse then another so, that he shall haue this gift also, that he wisheth to haue no more then he hath. Now, ô what ioy shalt thou then, ô my soule, and enioying be able to expresse when thou shalt be brought towards this Inne! shall not thy ioy there breake forth in most heauenly inexpressible mirth and musicke, making thee to say to the father! Holy, holy, is the Lord of Hoastes,
• say 6 3. the whole world is full of his glorie; stirring thee vpto crie to the Sonne. Thou art worthie ô Lord to receiue, glorie, and honour, and power; for thou hast created all things, and for thy wills sake they are and haue bene created. This ioy is compared to the ioy of a marriage, yea, with the marriage of Kings. Our minds be now narrower then they can comprehend this; albeit when the heauens shall receiue vs, we shall be capable of it so farre as a glorified creature may be. Lift vp thy selfe, ô my soule, and proue holy, wise, when thou hearest these things
if thou wouldst not be condemned in that great day by one who neuer saw that, who neuer heard that, which thou seest and hearest daily. Shall the Queene of the South hearing the fame of Salomon, and of the glorie of his court, and kingdome, long to see that which she heard, yea, vndertake and vndergo a long wearie iourney, to the end that she may see? and shouldst thou not, ô my soule, eate vp they selfe (as it were) within me, through longing and earnest desire; sparing neither for paines, nor expenses, till thou come to the chamber of that thy bridegroome; and to that Citie and Inne which is aboue founded, builded, garnished, and inriched as thou hast heard? for I assure thee, ô my soule, as the Queene of Sheba being come to Ierusalem, and there heard the wisedome, and seene the glorie of Salomon, was moued to say:1. King. 10. 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. It was a true word that I heard in my owne land of thy sayings, and of thy wisedome; howbeit I beleeued not this report, till I came and had seene with my eyes. But loe the one halfe was not told me, for thou hast more wisedome and prosperitie then, I haue heard by report. So thou, ô my soule, happily by Gods grace being by a liuely
faith ingraft in his Sonne, and without delay repenting thee of thy sinnes, and being by death transported to this his Inne of glorie, to see that with thy eyes, that which I heare onely with my eares, shall not onely find all these things to be there which thy God by his report, speaking to thee by his written word, shewes thee to be there; but thou shalt see, and seeing shalt possesse for euermore, ten thousand thousand degrees of more glorie, more ioy, more pleasures, then euer here thou hardst was there, or sawst here whilst thou liuest here, to be there. Shall Peter seeing but a glimps of Christs glory vpon mount Tabur crie out, (neglecting, yea, despising all he eue • heard or saw in Ierusalem, yea in the verie Temple of God at Ierusalem) Maister it is good to be here. And shalt thou not, ô my soule, thinke in a manner euill to be here on earth, till thou be where thy Iesus is cloathed with that glorie for euermore, farre surmounting that transitorie glimpse which Peter saw beneath here. For wert thou there, ô my soule, be sure thou shouldst say, and sing continually, O my blessed Maister! ô my sole sweetest Redeemer!
It is good to be here, it is onely good to be here, would to God I had bene here sooner; for there the Father is, the Sonne is, the holy Ghost is, his elect Angels, his chosen sonnes and daughters do liue onely, free of all feare of euill, possessed with a very sea of all good. And no wonder it be so, ô my soule, for here by the word of God we are onely acquainted (to speake so with his Maiestie) with the backe parts of God. But when we shall be transported to that heauenly Inne, farre remoued from all euill, and fully possessed with euerie good thing, as hath bene shewed thee, We shall see him as he is. The taste of this before hand moued Bernard to say:Bern. Infelicit as media in hoc seculo est pro qua gemimus, extrema in inferno quam merito formidamus: felicitas media in paradise vnde cecidimus, felicitas summa in coelis ad quam suspiramus. The midde degree of miserie is in this life, for the which we do sigh; the extremitie of miserie is in hell, which not without cause we do feare. The midde degree of happinesse was in Paradise, from the which we haue fallen; the onely great and extreame degree of all true happinesse is in heauen, after the which with sighing and sobbing we do

long and hasten vnto. And to conclude this point: this shall not a little augment the happinesse of the more then happie estate of the babes of God, being admitted within this Inne of glorie, & there admitted in soule, in bodie, as hath bene said, that being once possessed with these things, they shall neuer be depriued of them againe; but shall vndoubtedly enioy them for euer and euer. The things of this world thou knowest, ô my soule, be subiect to fading, for that shall neuer stand sure:1. Ioh. 2. 17. The world passeth away, and the lustes thereof. But as for these ioyes of heauen, they do resemble him by whom they be promised, by whom they be conquised, and who doth assure vs of them, and so be no wayes subiect to decay, but do last for euermore. And therefore Paul doth tell me that the elect of God in that day of iudgement (being caught vp in the clouds to meete our blessed Lord and Sauiour in the aire) shall after that,1. Thes. 4. 17. euer be with that our Lord. Wherefore ceasse not, ô my soule, while I breathe here to crie aloud, and to sing sweetly with the Psalmist: Sing ye loud vnto the Lord all the earth, Psal 100. 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. serue the Lord with gladnesse, come before him with
ioyfulnesse: know ye that euen the Lord is God, he hath made vs and not we our selues, we are his people and the sheepe of his pasture: enter into his gates with praises, and into his courts with reioycing, praise him and blesse his name; for the Lord is good, his mercie is euerlasting, and his truth is from generation to generation. Yea, to the end that thou mayst prooue truly and holily wise, ô my soule, see that while thou soiourne here, that thou vse the world circumspectly, as if thou vsed it not, knowing that the fashion of this world goeth away;1. Cor. 7. 31 and that thou rest vpon nothing but vpon that which is to be found in this Inne of heauen, euer remembring and neuer forgetting that of Augustine: August. Diuitiae si diliguntur ibi seruentur vbi perire non possunt; honor si diligatur, ibi habeatur, vbi nemo indignus honoratur; salus si diligitur, ibi adipiscenda desideretur, vbi adepta nihil timetur; Vita si diligitur, ibi acquiratur vbi nulla morte finitur. If riches be loued, let them be kept there where they cannot perish; if honour be loued, let it be had there where no vnworthie person is honoured; if health be loued, let it be desired to be found there where being once found there can be no feare to loose it; if life be loued,
let it be procured and purchased there, where it can be ended by no death.

div.head: THE GHVESTS ADMITted by our wise God (the sole Lord of this heauenly Inne) to enter and to lodge within it; be those alone who being members of his dearest Sonne Iesus Christ, be made in time by him true Christians, and so Prophets, Priests, and Kings vnto God their Father.
div.p:
THis Inne of heauen being the verie paradise and pleasant garden of the Lord our God, none can possibly be transported towards it but the trees of righteousnesse, who being the planting of God do here on earth glorifie his Maiesty.Esay 61. 3. This Inne is the sheepfold of that great Shepheard Iesus, and therefore none can enter into it but those who be the sheepe of Iesus,Iohn 10. 7. 14. 27. 28. hearkening to his voice, knowing his voice,Luk. 12. 32. following his voice, and refusing to here the voice of a stranger. This Inne is the wedding chamber of that glorious Bridgrome Iesus, that eldest Sonne,
and heire of the great King of glorie. And therefore none can be admitted to enter within it,Mat. 25. but those who being wise virgins, haue their lampes alwayes readie, and their oyle in them, attending in faith, and yet in feare, his comming. This Inne is the house of Christs Father, and therefore none can be suffered to enter within it, (albeit there be many dwelling places in it) but those who be the sonnes and daughters of God the Father,Iohn 14▪ 2. and so the brethren and sisters of Iesus, carefull to separate themselues from the wicked, and not attempting to touch any vncleane thing. But who contrariwise do cleanse themselues from all filthinesse of the flesh and of the spirit,2. Cor. 6▪ 17 18. & 7. 1. growing vp into holinesse in the feare of God, and alwayes (out of that hope they haue at length to lodge in this Inne) purging themselues more and more,1. Iohn. 3. 3. as God their Father, and Lord of this Inne is pure; for no vncleane thing can possibly enter into it, but such onely who hauing washed their long robes, haue made their long robes white in the bloud of the Lambe, and whose names are written in the Lambes booke of life.Reuel. 7. 14. 15. And so in a word, this Inne being
the royall palace of Christ that great Prophet, that high Priest, and that soueraigne King of Gods elect, none can possibly be honoured with it: but these who through this Christ are made Christians,Reuel. 1. 6. by the vertue of his Spirit, & meanes of his word and Sacraments: and consequently Prophets, Priests, and Kings to God the Father. Would I then, ô my soule, after my wearie labours here, be possessed with that worthie rest in heauen? I must studie necessarily before death to become a Prophet (for no ignorant shall come there) acquainted with the knowledge of God in his Sonne, and of my selfe in nature, and in grace, and so euery one who lookes for that Inne of heauen must know themselues to be miserable because of sinne; must know God to be mercifull, and readie to forgiue sinne, in his Sonne Iesus Christ; and must know that Christ dyed for them, and that his death became meritorious, deseruing and procuring remission of sinnes, and life euerlasting to them if they can beleeue in him, and repent. The sense hereof moued Paul to crie out: This is a true saying, 1. Tim. 1. 15 and by all meanes worthy to be receiued, that Christ came in the world
to saue sinners. 2. Cor. 5. 21 And againe: He hath made him to be sinne for vs, which knew no sinne, that we should be made the righteousnesse of God in him. Yea, our Maister in a word packing vp the whole matter of mans saluation doth say:Ioh. 17. 3. This is life eternall, that they know thee to be the very onely God, and whom thou hast sent Iesus Christ. Wouldst thou, ô my soule, after death liue within this Inne, before death I must be a priest offering vp to God my Father, Redeemer, and Sanctifier, not a dead, but a liuing, not a reasonlesse, but a reasonable sacrifice; yea not another beside my selfe, but my selfe vnto his Maiestie, remembring and reuerencing that holy charge sweetly giuen to me by that chosen vessell of Christ:Rom. 12. 1. 2. I beseech you brethren by the mercies of God, that ye giue vp your bodies a liuing sacrifice, holy, acceptable vnto God, which is your reasonable seruing of God▪ And fashion not your selues like vnto this world, but be ye changed by the renewing of your minde, that ye may proue what is the good will of God, aud acceptable and perfect. Thirdly, wouldst thou remouing from thy tent on earth be receiued within that Inne of heauen, ô my soule, which is the palace of this great
King, which carries this Motto vpon his thigh, The King of kings, and Lord of Lords: I must be a king, for this Inne is for no men but those who be kings, is for no women but those who be Queenes, and so who be true Christians. But what sort of Kings and Queenes be these, ô my soule, who shall rest within this Inne? men & women made kings and Queenes, not by God the Creator of the world, but by God that sole Redeemer of mankinde, and so by Iesus Christ who hath loued them, and washeth them from their sinnes in his bloud, and made them kings and Queenes vnto God,Reuel. 1. 5, 6. euen his Father. And so I see, ô my soule, that there shall not so much as one man, as one woman be admitted within the doores of this Inne of heauen, but he who is a Christian, but she who is a Christian, and that not so much as one true Christian shall be debarred from it. Thou art a king, but not a Christian, and therefore thou must stand without, & haue thy portion in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone. Thou art a Queene, but not a Christian, and therefore thou must stay without also, to be tormented with thy king. Thou art a
countrie clowne, and yet a Christian, and therefore thou must not stay without, because thou art a clowne but must go in because thou art a true Christian. But because in these our dayes there be such a world of men and women called Christians, and holding themselues for good Christians; I would haue thee, ô my soule, to trie who if these be Kings and Queenes made by Christ, & so fit ghuests for this Inne of heauen? Hearken vnto me speaking with a warrant of Gods word. None can be such Kings and Queenes, but those who can be seruants, and will be seruants; who cannot be seruants, nor will be seruants; who can be seruants, and will be seruants to him, who being the Lord of all, was heartily content to become a seruant for them; and so to that blessed and sweete Lord Iesus: who cannot, nor will not vpon any condition be seruants to any besides his Maiestie. Can the true Christian forget that ransome wherewith he was redeemed, and can he thinking on it be a seruant either to diuels or to men? No no, for he can neuer forget that of Paul. Ye are bought with a price, be not the seruants
men. 1. Cor. 7. 23. Ye were once darknesse, but now are light in the Lord, Eph. 5. 8. walke as the children of light. And thus the true Christian sees all these whom he sees in Christ, and cannot possibly see any out of him; he can honour and serue his king, his parents, his neighbours, alwayes in Christ, and for Christ but no wayes against Christ. And therefore he can mocke all honour, but that wherewith Christ is honoured; all pleasures, but those wherewith Christ is pleased; and all wealth, whereby his spirituall treasure is lessened, yea not augmented; and all life, but that life whereby his life Iesus Christ is conquised, and conserued by him: yea, he doth not onely misknow, but denie all friends and kindred, but those who in Christ be neare vnto him: in this resembling his blessed Maister who did all that he did for him; who suffered all that which he suffered for him; holding none for his mother, his brother,Mat. 22. 50. and sister, but those who do his Fathers will which is in heauen: and accounting all such who did this his will, for his mother, brother, and sister. Could this be considered, ô what a shame should couer the face of ye Christians of this age!
ô what a feare should possesse the hearts of the Christians of this age! O man thou wilt be a Christian, but not a king ouerruling the diuell? Thou wilt be a Christian, yet not a king maistering this wicked world, either alluring thee to euill by faire offers, or drawing thee from God, driuing thee to euill by threatnings, and punishments, but maistered by it? and that most willingly not eschuing sinne which thy Sauiour came to slay, but delighting in sinne which put thy Sauiour to death. Were that Marty Blandina Blandina. liuing to this day, sure I am she would say, albeit there be many men in the world now, yet there be wonderous few Christians in the world now. For in the midst of her torments she did crie out to the hearing of her Torturers.Clem. Alex. in orati ad gentes. Christiana sum, & nihil mali apud nos geritur: I am a Christian, and there is no euill thing done against vs. Sure I am, were Clemens Alexandrinus liuing, he would subscribe with her: for describeth he not a Christian thus? Is solus, qui pius est, ac religiosus, Christianus est: That man alone who is holy and religious, is a Christian. Oh, ô my soule, shall not these Christians who liued in the dayes of Eusebius arise in
iudgement against these of this our time. These in their liues were so religious,Euseb. Eccles. Hist. lib. 4. cap. 8. holy, chast, temperate, modest, that the verie fame of their liues, being brought to the eares of men, moued all sorts of people, casting off their natiue superstition, & forme of liuing, to turne to Christ; yea, the verie sauage Barbarions, by the report made vnto them touching the Christians, layed aside their barbaritie, and fiercenes, and embracing Iesus Christ, learned of him to be meeke and lowly in heart. Yea, what shall I say, ô my soule, if the Christians, in this our age find not grace in time to looke about them; the verie ambitious, curious, auatitious men among whom they liue, and whose carriage is knowne to them, shall accuse and condemne them. What ambitious man can content himselfe with the honour he hath gotten, and ceasse to aspire vnto a greater? what curious man can satisfie his eye with seeing, or his eare with hearing? Yea, what couetous man is heard saying, I haue enough, I will haue no more? And yet alas, ô how many blind senslesse Christians, deceiued by Satan and their owne lusts, and willingly deceiuing thēselues dreame
that they be alreadie sufficiently furnished with that future Inne, prepared for Gods children, albeit they haue neither oyle in their Lamps, nor a Lampe in their hands. Historie telleth me that Marcus Marcellus a Romane dedicated a Temple to the goddesse of Honour, but with all Historie tels me, that the way to that Temple of Honour was by the Temple of Vertue; and canst thou, ô man calling thy selfe a Christian, looke to be receiued within that onely honourable Temple, which is the mansion of that onely Lord, to whom all honour doth belong, & in whose presence true honour is onely to be found, vnlesse thou reserue (treading the way of vertue and valour here) to fight against the diuell, and to seeke and to serue thy God?Hier. part. The sense hereof moued Hierom to say.3. tract. 4. Portae duae sunt, porta Paradisi, & porta Ecclesiae; Epist. 20. per portam Ecclesiae intramus portam Paradisi. There be two gates, the gate of Paradise, and the gate of the Church; by the gate of the Church we enter into the gate of Paradise. Yea, this moued Bernard to say. Non rectised peruersiest animi, Bern. antea quaerere gloriam, quam excercere virtutem, & velle coronari qui legitime non certauerit; virtus
gradus est ad gloriam, verus mater est gloriae. It is not the nature of an vpright, but of a froward wicked mind, to seeke glorie before vertue be exercised, and to heare him desiring to be crowned, who hath not fought; vertue is a degree to glorie, yea, vertue is the mother of glorie. Bern. in Cant. And againe: Quid mihi cum victoria si non in praelio fui? impudētissimè mihi arrogo, aut gloriam absque victoria, vel victoriam sine pugna. What haue I to do with victorie, if I haue neuer bene in the battell? O how most impudently do I ascribe to my selfe, either glorie without vertue, or vertue without a fight. Learne therefore, ô my soule, in time to know Christ, in time to know what it is to be a true Christian, to the end that I may be perswaded that one day that onely glorious Inne of heauen shall receiue me, and receiuing me shall retaine me for euer; and so see that without delay thou learne to desire, betwixt the pretious and the more pretious, and so betwixt things seene which be temporall, and betwixt things vnseene which be eternall. O how manie called Christians shall be condemned of Iacob in that day of iudgement, and shut for euer out of the doores of this Inne of glorie! Iacob being
to receiue his brother Esau, when he feared, sent first before him his sheepe, oxen, and camels, after them he placed both his maides and their children, after them Leah and her children. But Rachel and Ioseph (as his most pretious and estimable treasure) he placed nearest himselfe, in the safest place: testifying hereby that he had rather loose all the rest, before he had loosed them. But alas the Christians of this our time, ô my soule, expose the onely best things (that is these heauenly graces which must leade them towards that heauenly Inne) vnder danger, and proue onely curious about the keeping of the perishing things of this world nearest them; testifying thereby that they had rather want Christ, and part with Christ, then any other thing beside him. Yea not onely shall they haue Iacob to condemne them who was the Lords holy confederate, but the verie brutish serpent, wanting soule, wanting reason; for natural prudence teacheth him to hide his head carefully when he is pursued, and to yeeld the rest of his whole bodie to the smiter, to the end that that being lost which is of smallest weight, he
may happily keepe that which is of greatest valour. But, alas, ô my soule, our onely blessed, and glorious head Iesus, is offered by vs at all times to danger, and we do keepe these things which cannot keepe vs, and which we shall not be able for our verie hearts to keepe long. O when shall men with Paul learne while they are here to know none,1. Cor. 1. to know nothing but Christ, and him crucified; to the end that in the day of challenge they may receiue this testimonie of Christ.Luke. 16. Thou hast chosen the best part which shall not be taken from thee. Bern. When shall that of Bernard written on these words: Behold we haue forsaken all things and followed thee, be considered by vs, Nec mutilis commutatio, pro • eo qui supra omnia est, omnia reliquisse; nam & simul cum eo donantur omnia, & vbi apprehenderis eum, erit vnus ipse omnia in omnibus, qui pro ipso omnia reliquerunt; omnia sane dixerim, non solum possessionis, sed etiam cupiditatis. Neither is it an vnprofitable chance to forsake all things for him, who is aboue all things, for with him all things are giuen also, and so soone as thou apprehendest him, he himselfe alone shall be all things, to all those who for him hath left all
things; yea, euen all things I say truly, not onely of possession which a man can haue, but of desire which a man can wish. Thou seest then, ô my soule, that thou must seeke thy God in this wildernesse of thy pilgrimage, if thou wouldst be found of him in that wished Inne of his glorie; that thou must serue him abroad as it were amongst strangers, yea, amongst sworne enemies, if thou wouldst reigne with him at home with his owne onely deare children thy friends. But here I will haue thee grauely to consider two things. First how shouldst thou serue thy God here? Secondly, wherefore shouldst thou serue him thus? Thou must serue him, ô my soule, frankly, and with ioy: and so neither from a grudging heart, nor with an auerse or froward countenance. Thou hast, I thinke, long ago acquainted thy selfe with the third petition of the Lords Prayer, Thy will be done in earth euen as it is in heauen: Hereby first confessing that thy God should be serued by thee here on earth, as he is by those celestiall spirits in heauen. Secondly, earnestly begging grace from his hands that thou mayst serue him so. Now couldst thou, ô my soule, learne to consider, and
considering to take to heart three things, ô how carefull wouldst thou be that thy God were alwayes serued by thee here on earth, faithfully, freely, heartily, and diligently, as he is by his Angels in heauen? First, couldst thou remember how these three sacred persons of that glorious Godhead concurred to make man, saying: Let vs make man to our owne Image? Secondly, couldst thou remember how heartily and gladly, that sweete meeke Lambe of God Iesus, offered himselfe to the death for thee, ô how heartily wouldst thou seek thy God, ô how gladly wouldst thou serue him? He is without Ierusalem, and if it had pleased him he might haue stayed without it: alwayes saith he not vnto his disciples:Mat. 8. 21. I must go vnto Ierusalem and suffer many things of the Elders, and of the high Priests and Scribes, and be slaine. And when Peter tooke him aside, and began to rebuke him saying: Maister pitie thy selfe, this shall not be vnto thee. Vers 22. Turneth not blessed Iesus backe this saying vnto Peter: Get thee behind me Satan, thou art an offence vnto me, because thou vnder stands not the things which are of God, but the things which are of men. Telling vs by these two things: first,
that he knew very well what would befall him at Ierusalem: Secondly, that he went vp most willingly thither, to the end that he might suffer these things there. Hast thou not, ô my soule, considered the 15. and 16. verses of the 22. of Luke? Then he said vnto them, I haue earnestly desired to eate this Passc • uer with you before I suffer, for I say vnto you hence forth I will not eate of it any more, vntill it be fulfilled in the kingdome of God. Telling his disciples hereby, that albeit he had eaten some Passeouers before that time with them, yet he neuer longed to eate any of those as he longed to eate this immediatly going before his suffering, so ready and willing was he to suffer. Hast thou lent thy eares to that prayer made by thy Maister vnto his Father? Father saue me from this houre, Ioh. 12. 17. but therefore came I into this houre. Yea, to close this point, pained it thee euer to reade and to weigh that conference (with those things fell out vpon it) thy blessed Sauiour hath with those who came to take him, registred by Iohn, in the 4. 5. 6. 7. and 8. verses of his 18. Chapter? yea, canst thou with this thinke vpon that speech spoken by this Iesus thy
sweetest Shepheard: I lay downe my life that I might take it againe: Ioh. 10. 17. 18. No man taketh it from me, but I lay it downe of my selfe. Shouldst thou not then seeke this Iesus, serue, this Iesus, both of purpose and with pleasure, who of purpose and with pleasure came to seeke and to serue thee? Thirdly, couldst thou consider, ô my soule, how frankly and willingly wicked men do serue the diuell, wouldst thou not be ashamed, yea afraid, if thou finde not thy selfe seruing thy blessed maker and sweet Redeemer, as frankly and willingly, as these do serue that euill one? Hath any wicked man receiued that, from that euill one, which thou, ô my soule, hast receiued from thy good God? Hath that euill one done or suffered that for any wicked man, which thy God hath done and suffered for thee? yea can any wicked man expect that from the hands of that euill one, which thou, ô my soule, mayst expect and must expect from the hands of thy God? The sense hereof moued Chrisostome to say: Turpe est impios diabolo tam strenuò seruire; Chrysost. Christianos Christo, pro pretio redemptionis nihil respondere, It is a shame that wicked men should so diligently and carefully
serue the diuell, and that Christians should recompence Christ with no good seruice, for the price of their redemption. Fourthly, couldst thou remember, ô my soule, how willingly, how ioyfully, thou seruedst thy owne lustes before thy conuersion, and so before thy God called thee from that damnable darknesse of ignorance, of infidelitie, and of impietie (vnder the which thou layest being in the first Adam) vnto this marueilous light of knowledge, of faith, and of begunne holinesse, wherewith thou art now happily adorned, being in that second Adam; wouldst thou not be ashamed not to serue thy good holy God after thy conuersion, as willingly and readily as before thy cōuersion thou seruedst thy wicked and vile flesh? O would to God that euery man had that grace bestowed vpon him, wherewith Paul was happily inriched before his conuersion, when he knew not Iesus, he ranne on foot and horse in euery place where he came like a furious lyon presenting those who called vpon his name. But after his conuersion I thinke he was as forward to preach Iesus for the conuersion and sauing of Christians; as he was furions before his
conuersion to persecute them for the profession of his name. Bernard thinking vppon this point, directs his speech thus to thee ô my soule: Erubesce anima, conuersa ad Dominum, Bern. ep. 34. minori affectu sectari iustitiam, quam iniquitatem antea sectata es: Causa enim est valde dissimilis, pudeat proinde negligentius in vitam, quam prius in mortem ire, & minori studio salut is acquirere, quam perauionis aug • mentum. Be ashamed, ô soule conuerted to the Lord, to follow after righteousnesse with lesse care and affection then before thou followedst after wickednesse: for the cause is verie vnlike, wherefore let it ashame thee to runne more negligently after life, then thou walkedst before after death, to seeke the increase of saluation with lesse care then thou soughtst before the augmentation of thy owne perdition. Bernard againe out of the sense of this doth crie sweetly and chearfully: Curramus non passibus corporis; sed affectibus, sed desiderij • , Bern. Med. sed suspirijs. Quoniam non solum Angeli, cap. 6. sed Angelorum Creator, nos expectat; expectat nos Deus Pater, tanquam filios, & haeredes, vt constituat nos super omnia bona sua; expectat nos Deus tanquam fratres & cohaeredes, vt fructum suae natiuit atis & pretium sui sanguinis Deo Patri offerat:
expectat nos Spiritus sanctus, cuius templum sumus. Let vs runne not vpon the feete of our bodie, but vpon our affections, but vpon our desires, but vpon our sighes and sobs, because not onely the Angels, but the great maker of the Angels expects and awaites for vs. God the Father expects and waites for vs, as for his sonnes and heires, to the end he may make vs maisters of all his goods. The Sonne of God awaites for vs, as for his brethren and heires annexed with him, to the end that he may offer and present vnto God his Father the fruite of his natiuitie, and the price of his bloud. The holy Spirit awaites for vs, as for his temple in the which he dwelleth here. O when shall the loose Christians of this our time take that to heart which Bernard wrote long ago for the wakening of sleeping Christians, and for the punishing of such toward that Inne of heauen, who looking for it step neuer a foote forward to the end that they may obtaine it? Qui in schola Christi non profecit, Bern. ep. 34. eius indignus est magisterio; praesertim tamen cum simus ibi vbi nihil in eodem statu permaneat, & non proficere sine dubio deficere est. Nemo igitur dicat satis est, sic volo manere; in via residet qui eiusmodi est, in scala subsistit vbi neminem
Patriarcha vidit, non ascendentem, aut descendentem. He who profits not in the schoole of Christ, is vnworthie to haue him for his maister, but specially seeing we are there, where nothing remaineth in that same estate: and where if men profit not by going forward, they must receiue hurt by falling backward. Let no man therefore say, it is enough I will abide as I am; he who is such an one sits still in the way, and stayes, without any motion on that ladder, where that Patriarch saw none but such, who was either going vp or going downe. Let me be carefull therefore, ô my soule, to walke with God with Enoch, to walke before God with Abraham, while I liue here; denying vngodlinesse and worldly lusts, and liuing holily, righteously, and soberly in this present world, not regarding where I die; not regarding how I die: for that is a taske almightie God hath not committed to my consideration but which he hath absolutely kept in his owne hands, willing me to be alwayes carefull to trie how I liue, but no wayes to be curious where, or after what manner I shall die. For I assure thee, ô my soule,August. that that of Augustine shall euer stand vndoubtedly true. Vndecunque mors
piae, bona est. W • ence so euer death cometh to the godly soule, his death is good: & therefore Augustine most wisely and louingly,August. doth thus strengthen and incourage the honest heart of the religious Christian walking with God, before God, against all feare of all death, and euerie sort of death. Noli timere, non potest male mori qui bene vixerit. Feare not ô good Christian he cannot possibly die euill, who hath liued well.

div.head: THE CONCLVSION.
div.p:
Let it not grieue thee then, ô my soule, y• that same day is hid vp from thee; that in some place vnknowne to thee, thou must lay downe this dustie tabernacle, wherewith thou hast for some yeares bene cloathed, as with a garment. But see that thou (being now happily ingrafted in Christ and through his grace dying to sinne daily for the which he died, and liuing to him who died for thee and rose againe) euen with an holy desire (submitting alwayes thy will to the good will of God) long for that day with that great Apostle, and when that day shall draw neere. I charge thee, ô my soule, that in that day thou lift vp thy selfe, and reioyce. What wise man being wearied all the day long with
laboures abroad, will grieue to draw home at night; first to refresh himselfe with some entertainement, and therefore laying aside his garments to go to his rest; knowing that (so pleasing God) when the morning shall arise he will find his garment againe. And darest thou, ô my soule, be aggrieued when that night of death shall approach, all thy wearie labours sustained by thee here being finished, to lay downe thy clay bodie, and to haue thy selfe conueyed by those Angels of God vnto that refreshing palace of that Paradise which is aboue now, wide open to receiue and to retaine thee, because of the obedience of that same Adam who died for thee? Yea, darest thou, ô my soule, be grieued in that night of death, to haue this clay bodie conueyed to that resting bed of the graue, sweetly now perfumed by the buriall of the sacred bodie of thy gracious Sauiour Iesus? for knowest thou not, when that glorious bright shining morning of Iudgement shall approach, in the which that mightie God thy Sauiour, whom the heauens do now containe, shall manifest himselfe in glorie, accompanied with thousands of
his Angels, and of the sound of the last Trumpet, that thou shalt not onely find that wanted garment of thy bodie, but take it vp againe, and put it on againe? alwayes not as men take vp their garments here in the morning, after their rest in the night, but farre otherwise; more comfortably, ioyfully, and profitably, by a thousand thousand degrees; as men here lay aside their garments at night going to their rest, so they take them vp in the morning, and taking them vp they go forth againe, either to their wonted or to some new labour. But I must tell thee, ô my soule, to thy great comfort, that thou shalt take vp this tabernacle of my bodie, in that shining morning of Iudgement, in a farre more excellent estate then it was layed downe in the chamber of the graue.1. Cor. 15. 42. 43. 44. It was layed downe in corruption, it shall be taken vp in incorruption: It was layed downe in dishonour, it shall be taken vp in glorie: It was layed downe in weakenesse, it shall be taken vp in power: It was layed downe naturall, it shall be taken vp spirituall. Could this be well considered, ô my soule, would I cease while I liue here, to employ all the
members of my bodie holily, and when death should approach me, would I not be heartily contented with ioy to lay downe this earthly tabernacle? Againe I will assure thee, ô my soule, (because so hath my Lord, and Maister Iesus, by the sweetest words of his owne sweetest lips assured me) that thou hauing in that day of Iudgement taken vp, and put on that garment of this bodie, shalt neuer go forth to any old, or new labours againe; but shalt alwayes rest in endlesse rest for euermore, free of all suspition of future griefes, and filled with a verie sea of inexpressible glorie; for in that day thou being happily presented a chast virgine, well decked and trimmed with the ornaments of thy glorious husband Iesus, before thy glorious husband Iesus, shalt haue that marriage now contracted with him, solemnized and perfectly consummated; and then thy blessed husband hauing wiped away all teares from thine eyes, shall take thee into his most secret cabinate of glorie,2. Cor 11. 2. there not onely to see but to possesse for euer, that glorie which he possessed before the world was made. Could this be well weighed by thee, ô my
soule,Psal. 42. 1. wouldst thou not crie with Dauid? As the Hart brayeth for the riuers of waters so panteth my soule for thee ô God. My soule thirsteth for God, euen for the liuing God; when shall I come and appeare before the presence of God? yea, wouldst thou not crie with Paul. Rom. 7. 24. O wretched man that I am who shall deliuer me from this bodie of death, I desire to be loosed and to be with Christ, which is the best of all. Yea, wouldst thou not crie with Augustine, August. sol. Eia Domine, moriar vt te videam, cap. 1. videam te vt hic moriar; nolo viuere, volo mori, dissolui cupio & esse cum Christo, mori desidero vt videam Christum. Viuere renuo vt viuam cum Christo. God my sweet Lord, Let me die to the end I may see thee; let me see thee, to the end I may die here. I will not liue, I will die here, I desire to be desolued and to be with Christ. I desire to die to the end that I may see Christ, I refuse to liue, to the end that I may liue with Christ. And to conclude, ô my soule, (praying my God to blesse thee with the longing and earnest desire of Dauid, of Paul, & of Augustine) wouldest thou not crie vncessantly with the Church, Christs bride, Come Lord Iesus: Euen so, come quickly. Amen,
